loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena U. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin province. She is 41 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Lucena owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Lucena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mateo

texts.es:
Mateo tiene 51 años, es un hombre que se siente realizado y feliz al haberse casado con el amor de su vida, Elva de 48 años, con quien tuvo 3 hijos, de los cuales sólo viven con Mayner de 21 años.   

Él recuerda que para pagar la educación de sus hijos, llevaba lo poco que sembraba directo a venderlo y casi no miraba ganancias, hasta que hace 30 años, junto a su esposa, compró grandes extensiones de terreno donde actualmente cultiva maíz, arveja, alfalfa y papa, lo que le permite obtener mayores ingresos económicos con los cuales compro más chacras, construyó su casa y ahora vive cómodamente. Mateo admira mucho a su esposa, pues ella es la gran gestora de todos sus logros, porque es una mujer emprendedora y decidida que supo destinar bien el dinero que llegaba a sus manos. Actualmente está ahorrando para más adelante poder construir una casa de hospedaje, con la que genere otros ingresos económicos.

Este es el octavo préstamo que tiene con MFP y está seguro que podrá acceder a futuros créditos porque refiere que sus ahorros, sus pagos puntuales y su participación activa en su banco comunal le garantizan como una persona responsable. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará varios sacos de abono para sus cultivos de papa, alfalfa y maíz.
texts.en:
Mateo is 51. He is a man who feels fulfilled and happy for having married the love of his life. Elva is 48, and together they had 3 children. Mayner, 21, is only one who still lives at home. He remembers that to pay for his children’s schooling, he took the little that he harvested and sold it directly and received almost no profits. That was until 30 years ago when, with his wife, he bought big pieces of land where he currently grows corn, peas, alfalfa and potatoes. This allows him to have greater profits. He uses these to buy more farmland, and to build his house where he now comfortably lives. Mateo admires his wife very much because she is the facilitator of his success; she is a good businesswoman and he realized that she would know what to with the money that came into her hands. They are saving now so that in the future they can build a rooming house to provide another source of income. This is the eighth loan he has with MFP and he is sure that he will be able to have more loans because of his savings, his punctual repayments, and his active participation in his communal bank. All these show that he is a responsible person. With the money that he is asking for now he will buy some sacks of fertilizer to use with his crops of potatoes, alfalfa and corn.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma es una mujer experta en el comercio, tiene 61 años pero se siente muy joven, pues está feliz al vivir en la casa que construyó con tanto esfuerzo con el compañero D. su vida, Antonio D. 62 años; ambos tuvieron 4 hijos que ya tienen sus propias familias.

La demanda D. la carne D. cuy la animó a que se dedique a la crianza D. este animal desD. hace 43 años, pero a su vez tiene gallinas, cerdos y carneros que venD. en las ferias semanales D. su ciudad. Paralelamente siembra maíz, papa, arveja y flores (gladiolos). Las ganancias que percibe le permiten vivir cómodamente, alimentarse a base D. comida natural y su familia tiene una adecuada calidad D. vida, por lo que está muy agradecida a Dios, quien los ilumina y bendice, refiere. Para el futuro, desea incrementar la cantidad D. cuyes que tiene, para lo que ya ha destinado un terreno amplio donD. sembrará alfalfa para alimentarlos.

Este es el séptimo préstamo que tiene con MFP y está muy agradecida con los integrantes D. su banco comunal, quienes siempre la apoyan desinteresadamente, pues entre todos se consideran una familia. Como empieza la campaña D. siembra, con el dinero que ahora solicita espera comprar dos bolsas D. semilla D. arveja y varios sacos D. abono para esparcir en sus terrenos.
texts.en:
Norma, 61, is a woman who is an expert in commerce. She feels younger than her age because she is happy to live in the house she built with so much effort together with her life partner, Antonio, 62. They had 4 children who all have they own families now. Demand for guinea pig meat motivated her to start raising these animals 43 years ago. At the same time, however, she raises chickens, pigs and sheep that she sells at the weekly markets in the city. In addition, she also farms corn, potato, peas and flowers (gladioli). The profits earned allow her to live comfortably, feed herself a diet based on natural ingredients, and her family has an adequate quality of life. For this she is very grateful to God, who blesses and illuminates them, she states. For the future, she wants to increase the number of guinea pigs she has for which she has already set asiD. an ample area to plant alfalfa to feed them with. This is her 7th loan with MFP and she is very grateful to the members of her communal bank, who always support her unconditionally because they all consider themselves a family. Since the planting season is beginning, the funds she is asking for now will be used to buy two bags of pea seed and several sacks of manure to spread through her fields.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seed and manure.

loans.name: Novelyn's Group

texts.en:
Novelyn F. is from the village of Turod. She is twenty-eight years old. Novelyn is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Novelyn F. group.

Novelyn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Novelyn owns and operates a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Novelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Novelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Novelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will Novelyn's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Celia

texts.en: Celia A. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 43 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Celia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Celia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Celia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Dipa

texts.en: Mrs. Dipa K. (see this note on Nepali names) is a resident of Sanepa, Lalitpur. She opened her grocery shop two years ago to improve the living standard of her family. Assisted by all members of her family, she sells a variety of grocery items in her shop such as rice, maize, biscuits (cookies) and snacks. Now Mrs. K. is requesting a loan to buy more grocery goods for her shop. She is planning to spend any increase in income to help her husband to improve the quality of life of her family. Mrs. Dipa K., lives with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law and her husband, Mr. Amit K., who works in a private office.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Marites' Group

Marites is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a furniture-making business in the manufacturing sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling dining furniture to local businesses and community members. Marites has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be Marites's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Ortizer

texts.es:
Ortizer es un hombre honesto y lleno de esperanza, tiene 50 años y vive en su casa propia con su esposa Gloria de 48 años y los hijos de ella: Cecilia de 15 y Excer de 11 años.   

“Cuando llegue aquí de mi pueblo, hace 4 años, no tenía nada de nada, no contaba con el dinero suficiente para sembrar y mantener mi chacra”, menciona. Ortizer empezó a trabajar como peón en diferentes chacras y actualmente contrata personas que le ayudan a trabajar sus propios terrenos agrícolas donde siembra plátano, café, carambola, maíz, yuca y otros frutos nativos. 
Lo que más le gusta de la actividad es limpiar sus terrenos, ya que después le darán buenas cosechas.
En sus planes futuros piensa preparar algunos terrenos que no usaba para incrementar su producción, también participará en un proyecto gubernamental de reforestación, por lo que plantará plantas ornamentales y maderables.

Este es el cuarto préstamo que tiene con MFP y junto a los integrantes de su banco comunal, quienes son muy responsables, agradecen por el crédito, pues éstos les ofrecen una nueva vida con mayores oportunidades. Con el dinero que ahora solicita tiene pensado comprar 7 sacos de abono y fertilizante, además de decenas de plantas de café que plantará en las chacras que recientemente compró.
texts.en:
Ortizer is an honest man who is full of hope. He is 50, and he lives in his own house with his 48 year old wife, Gloria, and their children. Cecilia is 15, and Excer is 11. “When I arrived here four years ago from my village, I did not have anything. I did not have enough money to plant and support my farm,” he says. Ortizer started to work as a laborer on different farms. He now contracts people to help him work his own farm land where he plants bananas, coffee, star fruit, corn, yucca, and other native fruits. What he likes most about his work is cleaning the land because afterwards it produces a good harvest. His future plans are to prepare some land that he does not use to increase his production and to participate in a government reforestation project. That is why he will plant decorative plants and wood producing plants. This is his fourth loan with MFP. He and the other members of his communal bank, who are very responsible, are grateful for the loan. They offer a new life with greater opportunities. He plans to use the money he is now requesting to buy seven sacks of natural and chemical fertilizers. He will also buy dozens of coffee plants, which he will plant on the farms that he recently bought.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and coffee plants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing livestock

loans.name: Rita

texts.es:
Rita tiene 39 años, está casada con Luis de 40 años, fruto de su amor tuvieron 3 hijos, pero sólo viven con Cristian de 8 años en una casa alquilada, sus demás hijos viven en otra ciudad.

Desde hace 20 años se dedica a la siembra de alfalfa, papa, maíz y arveja; paralelamente cría cerdos, carneros y vacas, de las que extrae varios litros de leche para elaborar quesos que comercializa en la feria semanal de la ciudad. Las actividades agrícolas las comparte con su esposo, pues ambos solventan los gastos del hogar y como buenos campesinos limpian y cuidan adecuadamente sus tierras. La dificultad se presenta cuando los productos bajan su precio en el mercado, por lo que ya no ganan lo esperado, pero Rita refiere que siempre hay ganancias, sino ya no trabajarían, pues si un producto baja su precio, otro sube y se compensa el trabajo que desempeñan, es así que piensa comprar más terrenos para sembrar en mayor cantidad.

Este es el décimo préstamo que tiene con MFP, donde viene ocupando uno de los cargos de la junta directiva de su banco comunal, donde aprendió a valorar el esfuerzo de cada integrante por salir adelante. Con los tres mil soles que solicita comprará otro terreno de cultivo, ya está en conversaciones con los actuales dueños, y allí piensa sembrar alfalfa.
texts.en:
Rita, age 39, is married to 40 year old Luis. They have three children, but they only live with eight year old Cristian in a rented house. Their other children live in another city. For twenty years she has been planting alfalfa, potatoes, corn, and peas. At the same time she raises pigs, sheep, and cows. She gets several liters of milk from the animals, and she makes cheese to sell at the city’s weekly fair. She shares the agricultural work with her husband, and they both pay the household expenses. As good farmers, they clean and adequately take care of their land. The difficulty occurs when the products’ prices fall in the market. Then they do not earn what they expected to earn. But, Rita says that there is always income. If there was not, they would not work. If one product’s price falls, another’s rises. This compensates them for the work they are doing. That is why she is planning to buy more land to plant in greater quantity. This is her tenth loan with MFP. She is on the board of directors of her communal bank, where she learned to value the effort of each member to get ahead. She will use the 3,000 PEN that she is requesting to buy another piece of land to cultivate. She is now talking with the current owners, and she plans to plant alfalfa.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a piece of land to cultivate

texts.en:
Brigid M. is a 58-year-old widow from the Lurambi area in Kakamega. She has five children with the eldest, Linet, being 35 years old and the youngest, Belinda, being 28 years old.

Brigid owns a restaurant which is a regular eating place in Kakamega town. Her clients mainly consist of employees who work in the construction companies in the area. The locals in the neighborhood also enjoy the delicacies she makes.

This is the second loan Brigid will be getting from KADET after servicing the first one very well. She is looking for Kiva lenders to help her get the funds to be able to buy cooking ingredients for her hotel like cooking fat, wheat flour and maize flour and to buy more plates for serving her clients.

Brigid hopes to do some renovations in her hotel (restaurant) for it to be more appealing to her clients.

Walter joined KADET recently and is now borrowing his first loan. He plans to purchase quarrying equipment and to hire people to expand his quarry. His business is located in a busy area and mainly targets those who are doing construction work.

In future Walter hopes to own several quarries for commercial purposes and to build a better house for his family.

loans.name: Alphas

texts.en:
Alphas S., a 26-year-old single man, lives in the Junju area in Kilifi, where he operates a motorcycle transport business. Alphas has served the residents of Junju for the last nine months and has been able to reap profits from his business.

This marks Alphas' second loan from KADET, and he plans to purchase a new motorcycle and employ a driver. A portion of the money will be used to insure the motorcycle. His business is stationed near a stage, and he is able to pick up passengers from vehicles to easily transport them to their destinations.

He hopes to dominate the Kadzengo stage with at least three motorbikes.

loans.use: To buy a new motocycle and to insure it.

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona L. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old, single, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Chona owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Chona has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Chona joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Cecilia Bañez' Group

texts.en:
Cecilia B. is from the village of Lutao. She is 49 years old and the leader of a three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Cecilia is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a livestock business venture in the agriculture sector. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Aside from her pig business, she also sells home-made longaniza (a pork sausage). Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2005, Cecilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her fourteenth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Kohe Asmai Group

texts.en:
Najeba is the group leader of Kohe Asmai group which has three members.

Najeba, who is 60 years old, lives in 10th district of Kheir Khana with six children: five daughters and one son. Her son is 20, single, and is a university student; three of her daughters are students and the other two support their mother in her business.

Najeba wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She has been a tailor for fifteen years and she is much experienced in this field. With the loan she receives she would buy an electric sewing machine to sew the clothes in a better way. 

Nazefa wants to take a loan for her husband’s business selling dry fruit. He wants to buy necessary materials for his business.

Tamana wants to take a loan for her metal shop business. She is a hardworking woman and tries to have a comfortable life and educate her children.

Together, the three group members have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani. They would like to mention the effectiveness of the Kiva process and its effect on their business progress.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Miriam Namaemba

texts.en:
Miriam V. is 40 years old and is from Kakamega town. She is married to Tom V. and they have three children who are still in primary school.

Miriam has applied for two previous loans from KADET and has repaid them well and on time. She is now applying for her third loan and she can testify that the two previous loans enabled her to expand her business.

Miriam started with the salon and as the business grew she then opened a side boutique. This was a wise idea since the clients who come to have their hair done get the chance to try on new outfits and handbags.

Miriam hopes to get Kiva lenders to assist her in buying more clothes, handbags and shoes for her boutique and shampoo, rollers and towels for her salon. She hopes to expand her hairdressing salon to be able to accommodate more clients.

loans.use: To buy clothes, handbags, rollers and towels to add to her stock

Mirzomiddin Y. lives in the Djalaladdin Rumi region. He is 27 years old, married and has three children. Mirzomiddin did not complete higher education. He is engaged in raising crops. Mirzomiddin has been involved in growing vegetables for over eight years. The loan enables him to purchase natural fertilizers. Mirzomiddin wants to have a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Leticia's Group

texts.en:
Leticia M. is from the village of Mambabanga, Luna, Isabela. She is fifty years old. Leticia is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Leticia is married and has one grown child. To make a living, Leticia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Leticia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leticia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use as additional working capital and to purchase additional inventory for her business. This will be Leticia's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights, as well as legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. texts.en:
Mrs. Sar L. has been selling fresh fish in the busy local market for more than nine years. She buys the fish from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She was married, but divorced her husband. She has three children, two of whom are already married. One of her sons is an employee in a garment factory. 

Sar L. always finds it hard traveling anywhere because she doesn’t have a vehicle. To help with transportation, Sar L. requested a loan, which she will use with her savings, to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi D. is a 46-year-old nurse and the married mother of two children: Rehema, who is in college, and Roy, who is in secondary school.

Sidi has been in the business of rearing dairy cattle for the last eleven years and she has been selling milk to the residents of Mabirikani estate in Kilifi.

Sidi is now borrowing her second loan from KADET after servicing her first one well. With this loan she intends to purchase one more dairy cow and to also buy dairy feeds.

Sidi hopes to own a large dairy farm for commercial purposes in order to be able to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and feeds for her cattle

texts.en: Vat H., age 50, is married and resides with her husband in the Takeo Province of Cambodia. She has six children. She is engaged in the business of selling various kinds of groceries from home, earning an approximate income of 3 USD per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially for her children's education. She has been with this business since 2003. Her husband is a skillful fisherman, earning an income of 1 USD per day. Their standard of living has improved, since H. has been with this business. She wants a loan in order to expand her business. H. is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to purchase a motorbike with an attached compartment (tuk tuk). This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. (H. is pictured with her husband in the photo.)

loans.name: Negena - One Group

texts.en:
This is Negena - one Group which consists of four female members. The group leader is Negena.

Negena is 35 and the mother of three children who are at school. She and her husband have a shared business. They buy fresh vegetables and fruits which Negena brings home. She cleans them all and packages them. Then, her husband sells them from his cart at a high price.

Negena needs the loan to hire a stall and purchase more vegetables to expand their shared business. 

Lema wants to take a loan for her husband’s business selling fruit from a cart. With this loan he wants to rent a new shop for his business.

Torpeki wants to take a loan for her son’s business selling cosmetics. He wants to make his shop larger.

Geta wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store. He has to work hard to earn money for the payment of household expenses.

Together they have requested a group loan of 56,000 Afghani. They are very happy with this small loan system in Afghanistan which is able to support poor people in their country.

loans.use: To hire a stall and buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie N. is from the village of Molatuhan Bajo in Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Elvie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elvie is an employee in someone else's laundry business. Elvie has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Elvie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to use as additional capital to renovate her house. This will be Elvie's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the needs of her family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna P., 35, is a widow. She lives with her sister and niece in the Muk Kampoul District of Koh Dach, a famous island located thirty kilometers along the Mekong River roughly fifteen kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh.

Vanna has been a silk weaver since 1985, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

Vanna is asking for her first loan in the amount of 300 USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Lilia

Lilia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo P., age 41, is married and resides with her husband in the Takeo Province of Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in selling handmade brooms, earning approximately 1.5 USD per day. By doing this, she is able to cover family expenses, especially for her children's education. She has been in this business since 1998. Their standard of living has improved, since P. has been in her business. P.'s husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 3 USD per day. P. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Joveryann's Group

texts.en:
Joveryann R. and her children are from the village of Balatacan in Tangub City. She is 32 years old. Joveryann is the leader of a two-member loan group sponsored by GDMPC. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repayingthe loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Joveryann is widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Joveryann owns and operates a retail store where she sells daily-use products, such as candies, biscuits, sugar, salt, shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Joveryann has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Joveryann joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joveryann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. Joveryann is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Joveryann from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Her husband is a policeman. She has nine children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie B. is 29 years old and a resident of P4 Silangit, Tangub City. She is married, and they are blessed with three school-age children. Analie's husband, Noel, is a painter, earning an average of not less than 5000 PHP per month. They were experiencing a financial crisis, and, to help her husband, she decided to engage in a sari-sari store (general store) business. For eight years she has sustained this business activity. She is now earning an average net income of not less than 3000 PHP per month. She says this amount is so helpful for their family income.

As a member of PMPC, she is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to add capital to her existing sari-sari store business. She is hoping that someday all her children will finish their studies and will find good jobs.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., age 35, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in a business of selling handmade brooms, earning approximately 1.5 USD per day. By doing this, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially for her children's education. She has been in this business since 2002. Her husband is employed as a bodyguard, earning an income of 3 USD per day. Their standard of living has improved, since S. has been in her business. She wants a loan in order to expand her business. S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to purchase more brooms for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. (S. is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: buy more brooms for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose M. is 55 years old from Esichirai in Kakamega town. She is married to Arnest M. and they have three who are all married.

Rose applied for her first loan with Kadet Ltd., which she paid well without any difficulties. She is now considered a client with a good credit history. She is applying for the second loan and she intends to use it to buy another cow. 

Her primary business is selling milk, which she gets after milking her dairy cows. Her customers mainly consist of shops and the neighbors, whom she normally delivers to very early in the morning as many of them use the milk for making breakfast and the enjoyment of a good cup of tea.

Her dream is to be a big dairy farmer, supplying milk to the dairy companies in her area.

loans.use: Buy another dairy cow

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
Sarantuya is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Sarantuya operates a consumer goods retail business, with the help of her husband, in a rented stall at a local market. They sell different kinds of consumer goods such as socks, shoes, oil, soap, detergent, etc. She began her business in 2002 and over the years, her business has grown and become successful. Now her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (about $1,400). In the near future, she is planning to increase her product line and grow her customer base. 

She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more home goods, such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes, etc., for her growing business.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mr. Sophea O. (pictured with his sister), 24, is single. He lives with his sisters and brothers on an island of the Mekong River approximately 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh City. 

Sophea has been a motorcycle repairer for over four years. He is asking for his first loan in the amount of $800 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

texts.ru: Бурхонов Миргосиддин проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 24 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Миргосиддин имеет среднее образование. Он более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. В этой деятельности ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Миргосиддин хочет внести удобрения и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en:
Mirgosiddin B. lives in the J. Rumi region. He is 24 years old. He is married and has two children. His wife is a homemaker. Mirgosiddin has secondary education. He has been a farmer plant grower for more than six years. His wife helps him in this business. He is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. Mirgosiddin wants to use the fertilizer to have a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

texts.en:
Mr. Heng C., 48, and his wife, Mrs. Nat Mao, 43, have been married since 1985 and have six daughters, two of whom are married and live outside the family home while the other four are in school. Besides his daughters, he also has his sister living with him. They live in a small village located seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. Heng was not available for the photo so his wife is shown instead.
	
Heng has been a construction contractor for twenty years. He works in his village and sometimes in Phnom Penh. His wife stays at home and does housework.

Heng is asking for his first loan in the amount of $500 to repair his daughter’s house.

texts.en: Mr. Soeurn H. is 40 years old, married and lives in Kdei Tnaot village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Mith Parch, are farmers who own a 1.50-hectare field on which they cultivate rice. They work hard, but are not able to earn enough money to support their family. His wife hopes to address this problem by starting a new business breeding ducks, and to make this possible, he has applied for a loan for 1,800,000 Riel to buy ducklings and feed. This couple has five children, four of whom are students in the local school, and also supports their parents, only one of whom is still able to farm for a living.

loans.name: Menza

texts.en: Menza B. is 43 years old, married, and has two children. He runs a nursery school in Mtongwe and also does double-duty as a teacher. He is a member of KADET and is applying for a new loan, his second, to improve his school. This new loan, for Kshs. 12,000, will allow him to purchase teaching materials and other much-needed items, such as stationery. His school mainly serves the community and families around Mtongwe, but he hopes it will become fully established and the school of choice for educating local children.

loans.use: To buy an assortment of items for a local school.

loans.name: Siem

Mrs. Touch P. is a 34 year old married woman who lives in Prey Mien village, Takeo province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Sophal Chhim, is a palm juice collector. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

The couple has four children, two of whom support their parents working and two others are students in the public school.

Although they try to work hard with two business activities, they still earn little income to support the family's living. Thus they want to start a new chicken business. In order to do this Mrs. Touch P. decided to ask for a loan to buy chickens to resell and the rest of the loan she will use to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding.

With this loan, income will increase and the living situation will improve too.

loans.use: To buy chickens to resell and to buy piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 33 years old and married with two children, ages 4 and 1, who have yet to start school. He runs a mixed farm in the western region of Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where he has been farming for over ten years. He has diversified his production in recent years and now sells eggs, chickens, maize, beans and tomatoes in his hometown.

When not too busy with the farm, he also earns additional income by making and selling bricks. Overall, the main challenge that he faces is the risk of disease spreading through the area and infecting his livestock.

Joseph has successfully completed three previous loans with Juhudi Kilimo, and has now requested this loan for KES 30,000 to expand his stock of poultry. He says that the extra income from this loan will help take care of his family's basic needs, now and in the future.

In the coming years, he would like to continually expand his business and he hopes to acquire additional chickens, keeping both the local breeds and some new exotic types.

Joseph is optimistic for the future and he has high hopes that Juhudi Kilimo will uplift him from his current position to a more comfortable life.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project.

She loves this business because it gives her joy when her customers come to purchase yams. She is hoping for the loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more yams to sell. She hopes to grow her business. 

Helen is 45 years old and married to a welder and they are blessed with 5 children. Her children are excelling in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun H. is a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Kouk Doung village, Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1-hectare field to cultivate rice on. Although they try to work hard at their farming, they still earn very little income to support their family.

Mrs. Chanthoeun H. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks and duck food to enlarge her business and increase her income and improve her living conditions. This couple has two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger one is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more ducks and duck food

loans.name: Oeut

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeut N., age 29, raises many pigs in a stall next to her house, and earns she earns a living from this work. She breeds and sells her pigs at least twice a year and has been in this business for more than three years. 

Oeut N. is married and two young children who are enrolled in primary school. Her husband, who appears in the picture, helps to support the family by selling fish in the market. For many years, Oeut N.'s husband has been spending a lot of money on taxis to transport his fish, because he doesn’t own a vehicle. Therefore, Oeut N. is seeking a loan to be used to buy a motorcycle for her husband's fish business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Gleen

texts.en:
Gleen L. is from the village of Cabu-an, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. He is 29 years old. Gleen is single. To make a living, Gleen owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing transport services using his motorcycle as a "habal-habal" driver. Gleen has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gleen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gleen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. Gleen decided to request the same loan amount as his previous loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Gleen from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partnersof Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Nafissatou

texts.fr: Y. Nafissatou est née le 16 Février 1987 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à DJIVO Ignace, un plombier, Nafissatou est mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. La famille vit au quartier Dégo à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Nafissatou n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer les différentes charges, Nafissatou vend divers produits de mercerie et des sachets à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Nafissatou s'approvisionne. Nafissatou exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et a déjà bénéficié de crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Très sollicitée par sa clientèle, Nafissatou  n'arrive plus à faire face à toute la demande de sa clientèle. Nafissatou sollicite donc un autre cédit auprès de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Nafissatou Y. was born on February 16, 1987 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Ignace Djivo, a plumber, and is the mother of three children, a few of whom attend school. The family lives in the neighborhood of Dégo in Cotonou. Both parents provide for their family. Nafissatou did not attend school. To pay for the expenses, Nafissatou sells various haberdashery articles and bags, both at home and hawking. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this trade for seven years and was granted a few loans by Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. Her products are in high demand and she is unable to fully meet her customers' demand. This is why Nafissatou came to Alidé and applied for another loan, which she will use to bolster her business and better meet her customers' demand.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various haberdashery articles and bags

loans.name: Mercy's Group

texts.en:
Mercy L. is from the village of Awallan, Baggao, Cagayan. She is fifty years old. Mercy is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Mercy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mercy owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Mercy has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Mercy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy  successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be Mercy's ninth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn V. (pictured here), is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Sokra In, is 41 years old. They live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1995 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them are in school.   

Sarorn has been a silk weaver for seven years, a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband is a silk weaver as well. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then takes them to re-sell in Phnom Penh market. Sarorn is requesting her first loan of US$ 250 to purchase silk materials for her waving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en:
Tabu B.  is currently in the business of selling groundnut-paste, bread and charcoal and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of groundnuts for paste. She is a 38-year-old widow with four school-age children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock groundnuts to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: additional capital for her sari sari store

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma P. is from the village of Cabu-an, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old, separated with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a retail business buying and selling coconuts in the local market. Elma has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Subhiya

texts.en:
Subhiya has three sons and one daughter. Two of her sons work and support the family along with their father: one of them works in the Occupied Palestinian Territories (Israel) and the other works in the vegetables market of Jineen. The other two children are school students. Subhiya's husband, Jameel, appears in the photo.

Subhiya is a housewife. She applied for a loan from FATEN to buy needed items for the new house they moved to. The family's old house was small and now that her children are growing up she and her husband thought of moving to a bigger one.

Subhiya and her husband think of building their own house once their financial situation gets better.

loans.use: To purchase needed items for the house

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita S., a resident of Sanepa, lives in a single family home with her husband, Mr. Surendra S., and their two children. Her daughter is studying in grade 5 and her son is in primary school.

Both Mr. and Mrs. S. are engaged in business in a small restaurant which they opened two years ago. They make different items of Nepali food in their restaurant, and they prefer to make dal bhat (cooked or steamed rice and lentil soup) in their shop. They also serve tea and coffee to their customers.

Mrs. S. is requesting a loan of Rs 15,000 to buy various types of food ingredients for their business.

loans.use: To buy food ingredients

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio M. is from the village of Baculud, Iguig, Cagayan. He is forty-nine years old. Antonio is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Antonio owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Antonio has been engaged in his business for over twelve years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP every harvest (every four months).

In 2007, Antonio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonio  successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. Antonio is requesting a new loan of 33,000 PHP, which he will use to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be Andres's sixth loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Jenilyn

texts.en:
Jenilyn T. is from the village of Cabuan Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Jenilyn is married and has 2 school-aged children.

To make a living Jenilyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Jenilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jenilyn joined HSPFI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenilyn successfully repaid her first loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jenilyn is requesting a second loan for 6000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to invest the additional revenue in her business. About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience sells dried fish at retail prices to her customers. Dried fish is used in the preparation of mouthwatering Nigerian soup. The demand for her dried fish is high in her community.

She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50000 to purchase more dried fish to sell.

Patience is 40 years old and married to a commercial driver and they are blessed with 3 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Felicidad's Group

texts.en:
Felicidad B. is from the village of Remus, Baggao, Cagayan. She is thirty-three years old. Felicidad is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Felicidad is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Felicidad owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Felicidad has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP whenever she sells an animal she raised.

Felicidad joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicidad is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Felicidad's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Nean

texts.en: Mrs. S. is forty-nine years old and the good mother of a daughter who is single and working as a tailor. S. is a domestic grocery trader; she orders a variety of ingredients from suppliers for her store and resells them to earn income. To help feed her family, her husband works driving a motorbike taxi around the community. The income from S.’s husband has been declining because his existing taxi needs repairs and is not very attractive. Because of this, S. is looking for a loan that will allow her husband to replace his old taxi, so he will able to attract his passengers. (S.'s husband is in the photo.)

loans.use: For her husband to repair his taxi.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Née en 1957 à Djougou au Nord du Bénin, K. Pauline vit depuis 12 ans à Aglangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à ADOUWEKONOU Christophe un pêcheur, Pauline est mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. C'est avec ses enfants et son mari que Pauline vit. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Pauline n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Pauline mène comme activité la vente de maïs à son domicile. Pauline s'approvisionne  à Abattoir, non loin de son quartier. Pauline mène cette activité depuis 13 ans et a déjà bénéficié de 6 crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Pauline voudrait accroître le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. C'est donc pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et augmenter son stock de produits, que Pauline sollicite un septième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Pauline K. was born in 1957 in Djougou in northern Benin. She has lived for 12 years in the neighborhood of Aglangandan in the Beninese town of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Christophe Adouwekonou, a fisherman, and is the mother of three children, a few of whom attend school. She lives with her children and her husband. Both parents provide for their family. Pauline did not attend school. To pay for her expenses, Pauline sells corn from her home based store. She gets her supplies in Abattoir, not far away from her neighborhood. She has been in this trade for 13 years and was granted already six loans by Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. She wants to increase her inventory to better meet her customers' ever-growing demand. This is why Pauline wants to increase her working capital and inventory, and therefore she came to Alidé and applied for her seventh loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of 100 kilograms of corn

loans.name: Rom

texts.en:
Mrs. Rom C. is a 46-year-old married woman who lives in Damnak village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare field where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Nao Run, is a key-smith who can unlock a key for profit. 

Mrs. Rom C. wants to take a loan of 2000000 KHR to buy a motorbike for transportation.

The couple has 7 children -- two are seamstresses, one is a laborer in gas station, one is a monk, and two are students in school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Mrs. Jesusa A. is 45 years old. She is from Upper Santo Nino, Mahayag Zamboanga del Sur. She is married with 4 children. She owns a duck raising business to earn daily income and her husband is also a farmer which supports their daily needs. Their farm serves as their main source of income. From her duck raising she approximately earns 3800 PHP a month.

She joined PMPC to gain access for financial support and to engage in other business activities. She successfully repaid her previous loan of 20000 PHP from PMPC. As of now, she has a new loan of 30000 PHP from PMPC and the purpose of that loan is buy a new set of ducklings. It is her 6th cycle of loans from PMPC.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her duck raising business.

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en:
Gerlie M. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is thirty-seven years old. Gerlie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gerlie owns and operates a service-based business in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing electrical repairs and installing Internet in the local community. Gerlie has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gerlie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gerlie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which she will used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. This will be Gerlie's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide her service

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine C. is from the village of Del C., Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 22 years old. Josephine is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Josephine is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Josephine is just starting this business.

In 2010, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Mrs. Lang P. is 58 years old and a villager who lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nuch Chea, are farmers who own a 8-hectare field to cultivate rice. They have a child who is a student in the local school.

Mrs. Lang P. is requesting 2,000,000 KHR from AMK to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to support her farming needs. Mr. Nuch Chea is a fisherman who can earn a small income from selling fish to support his family.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline.

loans.name: Chilbert

texts.en:
Chilbert B. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 42 years old, married, and has school-aged children. To make a living, Chilbert owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing construction services to local community members. Chilbert has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Chilbert joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Chilbert is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his services. This loan will be his second from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed for his construction business

loans.name: Glenda's Group

texts.en:
Glenda K. is from the village of Little Tadian. She is 37 years old. Glenda is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Glenda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Glenda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Glenda has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2010, Glenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Glenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Naret

texts.en:
Mrs. Naret C. and her husband, Mr. Moeun Sok, live in a small village about 17 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1994 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them are in school and the youngest one stays at home.

Naret has been a tailor for more than 2 years. She operates her business at home. Her husband has been a driver for a company for more than 4 years. Naret used Kiva to ask for a loan one time already. She now is requesting another loan in the amount of $300 to build a restroom for her famiy to use.

loans.use: To build a restroom for her family to use.

loans.name: Foluke

texts.en:
Foluke is 53 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state. Her husband is a soldier and he also supports his home.

Foluke sells dry gin at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more dry gin to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She hopes to grow her business.

Foluke says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dry gin to sell.

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr: Née en 1966, A. Pierrette vit depuis 19 ans environs à PK10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à FATON Bienvenu, un revendeur de graviers, Pierrette est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Pierrette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges familiales. Pierrette n'a pas été à l'école. C'est depuis 15 ans que Pierrette vend de l'akassa (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs), dans son quartier. Pierrette vend également de façon secondaire, des poissons frits à PK10. Pierrette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Pobè dans le département du Plateau. Pierrette a déjà obtenu plusieurs crédits à ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Pierrette sollicite un autre crédit de ALIDé, en vue d'augmenter son capital et d'élever le niveau de son activité. Ainsi, Pierrette pourra mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle et se faire plus de profit.
texts.en:
Born in 1966, Pierrette A. has lived in the PK10 neighborhood of the Sèmè-Podji area of Bénin for 19 years. She is married to Faton Bienvenu, a used gravel salesman, and has four children who are all in school. The couple takes care of the family expenses together. Pierrette has never been to school. For 15 years, she has sold akassa (a local food made of corn starch) in her neighborhood. As a supplement, she also sells fried fish in PK10. Pierrette stocks up on supplies at Dantokpa, an international market in Bénin and in Pobè, in the province of Plateau. Pierrette has already repaid several loans from Alidé and requests another loan to increase her working capital and to improve the level of her activities. In this way, she will be able to better respond to the demands of her customers and to increase profits.

Translated from French by Flavia Garcia (vol), Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 100 kg of maize

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Eng S. is a Cambodian rice farmer who has been working in this sector in a village located in Battambang province for more than nine years. Her husband helps her be responsible for their family by working in the construction field. She is aged 46 years and has given birth to three children. Two of them are employed and the other one attends school. 

Eng S. will use this loan to add to her savings and buy a new motorcycle which will enable her to travel anywhere; then she will buy a sewing machine to begin a sewing service for extra income.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Oem

texts.en:
Mrs. Oem R. is a 59-year-old married woman who lives in Daeum Pou village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Choup Ok, are farmers who own a 5 hectare field to cultivate rice. They have three children, one of whom is seamstress, one is a farm laborer and one is a student.

In this farming they do not have enough money to support their farming. Thus, Mrs. Oem R. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and the rest of the loan she will use to pay for renting a water machine to support her growing crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to rent a water machine.

loans.name: Ankadignongongné Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Ankadignongongné ont en moyenne  39 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Wela, un des villages relevant de la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de produits alimentaires tels les condiments alimentaires,  les céréales, les articles de boutiques (lait, sucre, thé etc.)  et les fruits et légumes.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Ankadignongongné sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  1bidon d’huile alimentaire, des poivres, des tomates fraîches, des oignons, des aubergines, des paniers de grains de céréales et quelques  paniers de fruits et légumes. 
 Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  à Konobougou. Elles effectuent leurs ventes, à Wela, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 7.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Ankadignongongné group are on average 39 years old, with two children, and living in traditional extended family groups in Wela, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Konobougou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women met through family ties. They are in the business of buying and selling food such as condiments, cereals, fruits, vegetables and other items (milk, sugar, tea, etc.). Having properly repaid their last three loans, the Ankadignongongné women are on their fourth group loan which will be used to buy a cannister of cooking oil, peppers, fresh tomatoes, onions, eggplants, baskets of grains and cereals, and baskets of fruits and vegetables. They buy supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Konobougou. Sales are done in Wela at the Konobougou city market and in surrounding trade markets. Transactions are done in cash, retail, and on credit to male and female customers. They expect a monthly income of 7.500CFA for each member, to be used for expenses related to health, food, and school fees, with the rest reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by Flavia Garcia (vol), Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expand her inventory

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S. is 30 years old, married, and has three children. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Since 2009 she has been engaged in the agricultural sector of farming, earning approximately $1 USD per day. Through this business, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. The family's standard of living has improved since S. started her business.
S.'s husband is a recycler, earning an income of $3 USD per day. S. is now requesting a loan of $500 USD to expand her husband's business and purchase more recyclable materials for sale. This is her first loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more recyclable materials for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Bendiya ont en moyenne  30 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Wela  dans la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font l’achat et la vente d’articles divers tels les condiments alimentaires, les habillements,  les savons traditionnels,  les céréales  et  la restauration.
