Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Bendiya sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires, des sacs de  céréales  et des ingrédients pour la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  à Konobougou. Elles effectuent leurs ventes, à Wela, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of Bendiya Group, on average, are 30 years old and have two children. All of them live in extended traditional families in Wela in the subprefecture of Konobougou, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They have known each other through family ties and are active in buying and selling various articles, such as food condiments, clothes, traditional soaps and cereals, and running a restaurant. After having repaid their previous three loans on schedule, the women of Bendiya Group apply for their fourth solidarity loan which they will use to buy large quantities of food condiments, bags of cereals and cooking ingredients for the restaurant. They get their supplies in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and in Konobougou. They sell their goods in Wela, at the market of Konobougou and at the surrounding trade fairs, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 CFA francs each. They will spend part of their profit on healthcare, food and school fees and reinvest part of it in their businesses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Nav's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nav N. is a 54-year-old married woman who lives in Angk Chruk village, Takeo province. She is the village bank president of a 15-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, AMK. Each member's loan will be used for different purposes.
Mrs. Nav N. and her husband, Mr. Ok Koch, are farmers who own a one-hectare field to cultivate rice. Mrs. Nav N. wants to take a loan of 800,000 KHR from AMK to buy piglets for breeding, fertilizer and rice seed, and to hire someone to plow her land. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living. The couple has two children, both of whom are married. All the borrowers are presented in the picture but one of them cannot be seen.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding, fertilizer and rice seed, and to hire someone to plow the land

loans.name: Sarita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarita S. lives in Sanepa, Lalitpur. She lives in a family home with her husband and two sons, both of whom are currently attending elementary school. Mrs. Sarita and her husband, Mr. Puspa S., make baked goods. They have been in business baking cakes and cookies for two years. They sell their baked goods to local shops and markets.
Mrs. S. is requesting a loan to buy more ingredients to expand their business. They will use the extra income generated to expand their business further and send their children to better schools.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make baked goods

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin R. is 31 years old and married, with four school-aged kids who are dependent on her. For the past fifteen years, she has been planting crops in the village. In the business, she grows crops like rice and local vegetables. As another source of family income, her husband makes a daily revenue by working as a medical doctor. He usually goes to examine patients who are his nearby neighbors. 

Presently he doesn’t have enough medical supplies to furnish an examination room for his work. Therefore, Rin R. has requested a loan for her husband to purchase the required articles. (Rin R. was busy working on the farm when the photo taken, so her husband is shown instead.)

loans.use: To buy medical supplies

loans.name: Rosalina's Group

texts.en:
Rosalina M. is from the town of Dumalinao, Zamboanga del Sur. She is the leader of a three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Rosalina is 41 years old, widowed, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Rosalina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,500 PHP from PMPC. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her fourth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.


About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Koem Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem Sorn T. is a 46-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Andoung Samretth, Takeo province. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a laborer while the other three are attending the local school and also supporting their parents' farming. Mrs. Koem Sorn T. and her husband, Mr. Heang Roth, shown on the left in the picture, are farmers who own a piece of land upon which they cultivate rice.

Aside from farming, Mrs. Koem Sorn T. sells eggs, earning a small income that contributes to the support of her family. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy more duck eggs to resell and to enlarge her business, with the rest of the loan to be used to support her crops.

loans.use: To buy more duck eggs

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Danaya ont en moyenne  29 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Wela, un des villages relevant de la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de produits alimentaires tels les condiments alimentaires,  les céréales et les fruits et légumes
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  1 fût d’huile alimentaire, des poivres, des tomates fraîches, des oignons, des aubergines et quelques chargements de fruits et légumes. 
 Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  à Konobougou. Elles effectuent leurs ventes, à Wela, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of Danaya Group, on average, are 29 years old and have two children. All of them live in extended traditional families in Wela, one of the villages in the subprefecture of Konobougou, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They have known each other through family ties and are active in buying and selling food products, such as condiments, cereals, fruit and vegetable. After having repaid their previous three loans on schedule, the women of Danaya Group apply for their fourth solidarity loan which they will use to buy one barrel of edible oil, sweet peppers, fresh tomatoes, onions, eggplants and a few cartloads of fruit and vegetable. They get their supplies in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and in Konobougou. They retail their goods in Wela, at the market of Konobougou and at the surrounding trade fairs, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 CFA francs each. They will spend part of their profit on healthcare, food and school fees and reinvest part of it in their businesses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Sévérine C.

texts.fr: A. Sévérine C. est née le 29 Novembre 1976 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à WENON Abel, Sévérine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolariés. La famille vit au quartier Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 9 ans. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Sévérine n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a 5 ans environs que Sévérine vend divers produits (couscous, pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomate et de sardines, sucre, lait, riz, savons, mayonnaise, piles, bombons, etc.) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Sévérine vend de la glace et du yaourt à son domicile. Cette activité lui permet de faire face à ses différents besoins. Sévérine s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo. Sévérine a obtenu antérieurement trois crédits auprès de ALIDé. Ces trois crédits ont été tous bien remboursés. Sévérine envisage augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est pour cette raison que Sévérine sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sévérine C. A. was born on 29 November 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Abel Wenon, Sévérine is the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. The family has lived in the Lokokoukoumè district in the town of Sèmè-Podji for 9 years. The couple provide for the family together. Sévérine only attended primary school. For about 5 years, Sévérine has been selling various items (couscous, pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, sugar, milk, rice, soap, mayonnaise, batteries, sweets, etc.) at her home. Additionally, she also sells ice cream and yogurt at her home. This activity allows her to meet her various needs. Sévérine gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and in Lomé, Togo. Sévérine has obtained three previous loans with ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). These three loans were all repaid properly. Sévérine plans to increase the stocks of her products and better respond to the demands of her customers. It is for this reason that she is seeking a fourth loan with ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items (soap, sugar, milk, pasta, rice, couscous, canned tomatoes and sardines, etc.)

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda J. is currently in the business of selling bread at home and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice and salt to sell. Twenty-nine years old and married to a driver, Roda has two children, both attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice and salt to sell

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Erdenetsetseg is 51 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her son has been working as a trainee at the Temuujin theater, and her daughter is a first-year university student. They have been living in their current home for four years. Since they started their business, their quality of life has improved. Erdenetsetseg and her husband are planning to repair one of their rooms for their oldest son.

Recently, Erdenetsetseg has been operating a food kiosk beside their home. Her working capital is 400,000 tugrugs (~ 281 USD). Previously she worked as an attendant in a hospital until she retired. She is a very hardworking person and planning to expand her food kiosk, to repair their apartment and to purchase a variety of products.

She says, “I would like to be supportive and financially stable for my two children until they can live without our help.” She is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug (~ 844 USD) loan to afford payment of the room where the food kiosk has been running. Erdenetsetseg will spend 750,000 tugrugs (~ 492 USD) of the loan to rent the room and will purchase inventory for her food kiosk with the remaining 450,000 tugrugs (~ 316 USD).

loans.use: To rent a room and purchase inventory for her food kiosk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy bike parts and bikes

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhorn N., age 52, lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. He has five children: three sons and two daughters. One of his sons is a fisherman; another one assists his father in farming, and the other one attends school.

Sokhorn has been a farmer since 1979. He is also a fisherman and is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a rice threshing machine to use when harvest season comes.

loans.use: To purchase a rice threshing machine to use when harvest season comes.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna P. is from the village of Magsaysay, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Lorna owns and operates a store, selling rice in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Lorna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 12th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell

loans.name: Samei

texts.en:
Mrs. Samei K. is a villager who lives in Andoung Samretth village, Takeo province. She is 31 years old and is married with three children, two of whom are attending the public school while the youngest one is 3 years old.

Mrs. Samei K. and her husband, Mr. Arn Tuos, are farmers who own a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) field on which they cultivate rice and grow vegetables which has allowed them to support their family.

Mrs. Samei K. wants to take a loan of 1,500,000 Riel from AMK to buy a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona M. is currently in the business of selling groundnut (peanut) paste and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase jerrycans (plastic containers) of cooking oil to sell. Lona is 30 years old and is married to a business man. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a supermarket. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Djiguisseme ont en moyenne  34 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Wela, un des villages relevant de la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente d’articles divers tels les condiments alimentaires, les habillements,  les céréales, la  cola  et  la restauration.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires, quelques sacs de  céréales (riz, mil, haricot) et des ingrédients pour la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  à Konobougou. Elles effectuent leurs ventes, à Wela, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Djiguisseme" group are on average 34 years old with 2 children and live in traditional extended households in Wela, a significant town in the sub-prefecture of Konobougou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other through familial relations, and run businesses buying and selling various items such as food condiments, clothing, cereals, cola, and prepared meals. After having properly repaid their 3 previous loans, the women of the Djiguisseme group are on their fourth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy a large quantity of food condiments, several bags of cereals (rice, millet, beans), and ingredients to prepare meals. They get their supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Konobougou. They make their sales in Wela, at the Konobougou city market, and at the neighbouring area market-days, in cash, at retail, and on credit, to a clientele composed of women and men. They plan to realize an average monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA each, which will be used to pay for expenses related to health, food, and school fees, with the remainder being reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr: H. Victorine est née en 1969 à Sô-Tchanhouè au Bénin. Mariée à BOYIKI Abel, un commerçant, Victorine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 5 ans environs, au quartier Tchanhounkpamè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Victorine a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Victorine mène comme activité la vente de tissus, chaussures et des bols en séries à son domicile. Victorine vend également des amuses gueules, de façon secondaire. C'est au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, et aussi à Lomé au Togo, que Victorine se ravitaille. Victorine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Victorine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour reconstituer son stock de produits et se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Victorine H. was born in 1969 in Sô-Tchanhouè in Benin. Married to Abel Boyiki, a shopkeeper, Victorine is the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. The family has lived for about 5 years in the Tchanhounkpamè district in the town of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. The couple provide for the family together. Victorine ended her studies in secondary school. For about ten years, Victorine has run a business selling fabric, shoes, and sets of bowls at her home. Victorine also sells appetizers as a secondary business. She gets her supplies in Ouando in Porto-Novo, and also in Lomé, Togo. Victorine has already benefited from two loans with ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), both of which she repaid properly. Faced with an increasingly high demand from her clientele, Victorine is seeking a third loan with ALIDÉ to reconstitute her stocks of goods and generate a larger income.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes and fabric

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie T. is from the village of D’Ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Lenie owns and operates a general store, selling daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2003, Lenie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.

Lenie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 11th loan taken out by from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Ney

texts.en:
Ney C., 53, is a cleaner in a night club and started her work a year ago. She is a widowed mother who has given birth to seven children. Six of them are single and the other one is married. 

Ney C. has a daughter who is no longer in school and now works with her in the same field and place. Ney C. is taking out her loan to purchase a new motorbike, which she will use to ride to her work location. She is hopefully that the loan will help her reduce expenses from hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Batsuh

texts.en:
Batsuh is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children live at home now.

Batsuh works with his wife as a shoemaker. Currently, they do not have a place of their own in which to live, but they are planning to purchase a plot of land in the future. They live only on the profits from their business and do not have income from any other sources.

Batsuh started his business as a carpenter from his home in 2005. He has operated the shoe repair business with his wife and sister at the Ganbogd market since June of 2009. Since then, he and his wife have worked hard to expand their business. They are planning to work separately from Batsuh's sister and to purchase a plot of land on which to live. Batsuh says, “I would like to create my own workplace.”

The Mongolian Lunar New Year celebration is coming, and demand for Batsuh's services is very high now. For this reason, the number of his customers has increased. He is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to purchase shoe-making materials from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia in anticipation of the Mongolian Lunar New Year celebration.

loans.use: To purchase shoe-making materials

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni M. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol at the market and is requesting a loan to stock materials to use in her business. Poni is 26 years old and is married. Her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock materials to use in brewing alcohol.

loans.name: Nelybeth Pao  Group

texts.en:
Nelybeth P. is from the village of Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old. Nelybeth is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nelybeth P. Group. Nelybeth is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Nelybeth is engaged in farming cassava. Nelybeth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2007, Nelybeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Nelybeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed for her cassava plantation. Nelybeth is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to finance her cassava plantation. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Nelybeth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for banana, cassava plantation.

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yacouba C. est âgé de 40 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec ses quatre enfants et sa femme dans le quartier Fana coura, sous préfecture de Fana, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Monsieur Yacouba abandonna l’école en classe de huitième année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce d’articles divers. Yacouba est très sollicité et jouit d’une grande notoriété dans les activités d’achat et de  vente d’articles électroniques.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son troisième prêt individuel, après  avoir correctement  remboursés les deux précédents.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter,  20 téléphones portables et accessoires. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako à un prix abordable pour venir les revendre dans sa boutique sise au grand marché de Fana, à une clientèle composée de toutes les catégories sociales de la ville.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les dépenses de la famille et le reste investi dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Yacoube C. is 40 years old and lives in a monogamous household with his four children and wife in the Fana coura area, in the Fana sub-prefecture in the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Yacouba abandoned his education in eighth grade (in the Malian education system) to devote himself to income-generating activities, notably the buying and selling of various goods. Yacouba is highly sought-after and enjoys a good reputation in his business buying and selling electronic items. With the hope of better satisfying his growing clientele, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners), with whom he is on his third individual loan, after having properly repaid the two previous ones. He intends to use this loan to buy 20 mobile phones and accessories. He gets his supplies in Bamako at an affordable price, and then sells them at his store located at the grand market in Fana, to a clientele composed of all social categories from the city. He hopes to realize an average monthly profit of 80,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay for his family expenses, with the remainder being reinvested in his business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mobile phones

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a tire repair machine

loans.name: Borin

texts.en:
Mr. Borin H., age 38, and his wife, Mrs. Kimsan Ny (both available in the photo), age 31, live about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1996 and have two daughters. Besides his daughters, they also has his mother and grandmother living with him. 
Borin and his wife have been selling fish for four years. They buy fish from fishermen and transport tH. to sell in the village. Beyond selling fish, the couple also grows lotus. Borin is requesting a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase a motorbike to carry fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to carry fish to sell.

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara P. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and bread at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice to sell. Tamara is 50 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has 3 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of rice to sell.

loans.name: Lawal

texts.en: Lawal is 40 years old, married, and has a child. Her 9 years old child attends school. Her husband works to support the home. She sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a maternity home in the future. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state. She is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: Née le 11 Octobre 1949 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Madeleine est mariée à HOUNGUE Gérôme et est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais deux enfants sont encore à la charge du couple. La famille réside à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Madeleine vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les charges familiales. Madeleine n’a fréquenté que le cours primaire. Il y a près de 22 ans que Madeleine mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (savons, allumettes, bougies, conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, piles, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, papiers hygiéniques, etc.) à son domicile. Madeleine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé les crédits antérieurs qu’elle avait obtenu. Très sollicitée par sa clientèle, Madeleine ambitionne renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. C’est pourquoi Madeleine sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born on 11 October 1949 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Madeleine A. is married to Gérôme Houngue, and is the mother of five children, all of whom have been provided with some education. However, only two children are still in the couple's care. The family lives in Ekpè, in the town of Sèmè-Podji. Madeleine helps her husband in providing for the family. Madeleine only attended primary school. For close to 22 years, Madeleine has run a business selling various items (soap, matches, candles, canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, batteries, pasta, sugar, toilet paper, etc.) at her home. She buys these goods at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and has properly repaid all the previous loans she obtained. Highly sought-after by her clientele, Madeleine aspires to strengthen her business and better respond to the increasing demand of her clientele. This is why Madeleine is seeking another loan with ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items (soap, batteries, milk, pasta, canned goods, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Benkadi ont en moyenne  42 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Bouwere dans la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, des articles de boutique, du poisson séché, des tubercules, des fruits et légumes, des céréales et des habillements.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé  pour constituer un stock de condiments alimentaires, de poissons séchés et acheter  quelques sacs de céréales, de chargements de charrettes en fruits et   quelques complets d’habits pour enfants. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et à Konobougou auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes, à Bouwere (à domicile), au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 7.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Benkadi" group are on average 42 years old with 2 children and live in traditional extended households in Bouwere, in the Konobougou sub-prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other through familial relations and run businesses buying and selling various items such as food condiments, dry goods, dried fish, tubers, fruits and vegetables, cereals, and clothing. After having properly repaid their 3 previous loans, the women of the Benkadi group are on their fourth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to set up stocks of food condiments and dried fish, and to buy several bags of cereals, cartloads of fruits, and several sets of children's clothing. They obtain their supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Konobougou from producers and wholesalers. They make their sales in Bouwere (at home), at the Konobougou city market, and at the neighbouring area market-days, in cash, at retail, and on credit, to a clientele composed of women and men. They plan to realize an average monthly profit of 7,500 FCFA each, which will be used to pay for expenses related to health, food, and school fees, with the remainder being reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Mony

texts.en:
Mrs. Mony K. is a 32-year-old married woman who lives in Andoung Samretth village, Takeo province. She is a farmer and she also sells water in the local village. For her business she wants to take a loan of 2,000,000 Riel to buy a water machine, a cart and supplies to support her business. Her husband, Mr. Sokhorn Park, is a teacher in the local school. He receives a small salary to support his family’s living. 
Mrs. Mony K. is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her business.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 47-year-old married man and has one child. He has been working as a carpenter and furniture builder since 1984. He has always worked out of his home where he has prepared a special room for this purpose. And over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his family's needs. 

After this long experience in this occupation, Bilal is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to open a carpentry shop and make the needed preparations in order to develop his business by taking more orders from the clients and making more profit.

loans.use: open a carpentry shop

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Djekafo ont en moyenne  40 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Bouwere dans la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, de l’habillement, du sucre, du poisson séché, des tubercules et des fruits et légumes.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des  paquets de condiments alimentaires et de poissons séchés,  quelques sacs de sucre et quelques chargements de charrettes en fruits et patates douces. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  en gros en condiments alimentaires et sucre à Bamako (capitale du Mali), Konobougou et  sur place pour les autres articles. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes, à Bouwere, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Djekafo" group are on average 40 years old with 2 children and all live in traditional extended households in Bouwere, in the Konobougou sub-prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know each other through familial relations, and run businesses buying and selling various items such as food condiments, clothing, sugar, dried fish, tubers, fruits, and vegetables. After having properly repaid their 3 previous loans, the women of the Djekafo group are on their fourth solidarity (group) loan, which will be used to buy packets of food condiments, dried fish, several bags of sugar, and several cartloads of fruit and sweet potatoes. They obtain their supplies of food condiments and sugar in bulk in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Konobougou, and buy the other items on-the-spot. They make their sales in Bouwere, at the Konobougou city market, and at the neighbouring area market-days, in cash, at retail, and on credit, to a clientele composed of women and men. They plan to realize an average monthly profit of 12,500 FCFA each, which will be used to pay for expenses relating to health, food, and school fees, with the rest being reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Bayarjargal

texts.en: Bayarjargal is 22 years old and lives with her mother and child in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Recently, Bayarjargal's mother has been taking care of her grandchild in their home. Sometimes her mother cooks food and sells it to the salespeople who work at the market. In April 2009, Bayarjargal attended a beauty course in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. During the day, she operates a beauty service business in her own province. Previously, Bayarjargal had spent four years cooking food with her mother and selling it to the salespeople who work at the market. Bayarjargal is a hardworking and open person. She says, “I would like to expand my beauty services business into a  salon.” She is requesting a 280,000 Tugrug (~ 197 USD) loan to increase her working capital and to purchase equipment for her business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for beauty salon.

loans.name: Neng

texts.en:
Mrs. Neng N. is a 27-year-old married woman who lives in Andoung Samretth village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Oeung Soeng, are farmers who own 1.50-hectare field to cultivate rice. Aside from farmer, Mr. Oeung Soeng is a construction worker who can receive a small income to support his family’s living. 
Mrs. Neng Nhab is requesting 1,500,000 Riel from AMK to buy a motorbike to support her husband’s income. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work. The couple has one child who is too young to study or work. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: God's Will Group

texts.en:
Kuku D. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called God's Will. She is 35 years old and married with 5 children, aged 1-16 years old.  Their educational levels are kindergarten to 10th grade. Kuku was not able to attend school due to poverty. She and her family live in the Bernard Farm community in Paynesville, Liberia. 
 
Kuku's business is the sales of fish. She buys her fish wholesale from fishermen and sells retail on a tabletop to residents of her community in Paynesville.  She has been running her business for 5 years and hopes to grow her fish business in the future.

Talking to her customers in a nice manner is the secret to Kuku's success in business.  Kuku will use this loan to purchase additional fish for resale.  She dreams of providing her children with a good education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kuku is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish for resale.

loans.name: Umriniso

texts.ru: Мустафокулова Умринисо проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Умринисо более 5 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она продает продукты. В этом ей помогает муж. Он привозит продукты с города. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Умринисо хочет взять еще одну тоторговую точку на рынке.
texts.en:
Umriniso M. lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 39 years old. She is married and has three children. Umriniso has been selling on the market for more than five years. She sells groceries. Her husband helps her too. He delivers the groceries from the town. She is asking for a loan to increase sales. Umriniso wants to open another vendor location on the market.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Modinat

texts.en: Modinat sells groceries and jewelry at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her years of experience to attract and retain customers. She is 40 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her eldest child is 18 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this makes her happy. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Suzzi

texts.en: Suzzi L. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to buy beans, rice and posho (a hot, sticky dough or porridge made from maize or cassava) to sell. Suzzi is 28 years old and is married to a policeman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy beans, rice and posho to sell

loans.name: Salimatou

texts.fr: I. Salimatou est née le 24 Mai 1988 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à SAGBOHAN Ambroise, Salimatou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Salimatou a un autre enfant à sa charge, en plus de ses enfants. La famille vit depuis sept ans au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses différents besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Salimatou vend depuis 5 ans, divers produits (des cannettes, mêches, etc.) à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Salimatou se ravitaille. C'est la première fois que Salimatou sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui servira à renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
Salimatou I. was born on May 24th, 1988 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Ambroise Sagbohan, Salimatou is a mother of two schooled children. She also has another child in her care, in addition to her own children. The family has been living in the Avotrou quarter, in Cotonou for the past seven years. The couple takes care of the household expenses together. To account for her own needs, as well as for the needs of her children, Salimatou has been selling various products (canned goods, hair extensions, etc.) directly from her house. It is in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, where Salimatou gets her supplies. This is the first time that Salimanou is requesting a loan from ALIDE – a loan that will help her strengthen her business and better respond to the requests of her customers.

Translated from French by Dina Dumenko, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of canned goods (sweet soda drinks and beer)

loans.name: Kokadjiè Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Kokadjiè ont en moyenne  36 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Bouwere, un des villages de la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, de fruits, de grains de céréales et  d’habillements.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Kokadjiè sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé, pour constituer un stock de condiments alimentaires et acheter 3 douzaines d’habits pour enfants et femmes. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et à Konobougou auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes, à Bouwere (à domicile), au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de12.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Kokadjie group, on average, are 36 years old, have 3 children, and live with their traditional extended families in Bouwere, one of the villages in the prefecture of Konobougou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women have met through family ties, and now run a resale business of various articles such as food products, fruits, grains and clothing. After having properly reimbursed 3 previous loans, the women of the Kokadjie group are looking for their fourth loan, which will be used to build up their inventory of food supplies, as well as for the purchase of about three dozen articles of clothing for women and children. They get their supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Konobougou from suppliers and wholesellers. They sell their articles in Bouwere (from their houses), in the market of Konobougou, as well as in the surrounding fairs, for cash and credit, to a clientele composed of both men and women. They are looking to make an average monthly profit, of 12.500 FCFA each, that will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food provisioning, and schooling expenses for their families; with the remainder being reinvested in their business operations.

Translated from French by Dina Dumenko, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various articles for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Motor maintenance for the taxi truck

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Mr. Horn C. is a 49-year-old who lives in Srae Vong village, Takeo province. He is a father with four children, one of whom is a seamstress in the garment factory. Two of his children are students in the local school and the last one is 5 years old. 

Mr. Horn C. and his wife, Mrs. Sok Ses, are farmers who own a 2-hectare field to cultivate rice. In this dry farming season, Mr. Horn C. needs 2,000,000 Riel from AMK, a Kiva partner, to buy fertilizer, rice seeds and pesticides, and to pay for farm labor to support his growing crops. Aside from farming, Mrs. Sok Ses is a salt and vegetable seller who can earn a small income to help support the family. His wife is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seeds and pesticide, and to pay for farm labor

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is a 31-year-old father of four children who are in school.  He had a shop, which he operated for one year before he started a water kiosk. He is employed with KK security services in Nairobi, where he earns 12,000 Kenyan shillings per month while his wife assists him in his business.  

He has become an active member of Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, by saving money in the MFI (microfinance institution). He plans to buy a water tank at 40,000 shillings and a water booster at 10,000 shillings; hence, he has requested a loan of 50,000 shillings. He hopes to become financially stable by making more savings and generating more income. His dream is to have his own company in the future.

loans.use: Buy water tank and water booster

loans.name: Olubumi

texts.en: Olubumi is a hardworking woman. She opens her stall daily from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. to sell drinks and juice to her customers. She loves this business because she has the opportunity to meet one-on-one with her customers. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and juice to sell. She is 35 years old and married with four children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and juice to sell

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa is 35 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia.  Her two children go to secondary school. Her husband operates a taxi service with his own car. They bought their plot of land with a fence and a ger (a traditional Mongolin housing tent), where they have been living since 2009.  

Bayarmaa and her husband bought their car and plot of land using the profits from their businesses. During the day, she has been renting a room in the Urgoo trading center, near the Ganbogd market, for her hairdressing business. She started working as a professional hairdresser and started her business in 2000. She says, “I would like to establish my own workplace.” She is requesting a 120,000 tugrug loan to purchase products such as hair cream, hair dye and shampoo.

loans.use: To purchase products for hairdressing business

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Mr. Pich C. is a 46-year-old villager in Srae Vong village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Thouk Ouch, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare field to cultivate rice.

Mr. Pich C. is now requesting 1,400,000 Riel from AMK, a Kiva partner, to buy fertilizer, rice seeds, pesticide and gasoline to support his dry farming season. Aside from farming, he is a palm-juice collector and his wife is a salt seller who can make a small income to support their family life. This couple has six children, one of whom is a seamstress in the garment factory, while three others are attending the local school and the other two are too young to study or work. His wife is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seeds, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: One Love Group

texts.en: Nancy S. is the leader of a group five borrowers called One Love Group. She is 35 years old, married and has no children. She was not able to go to school because her parents died when she was in her youth. Nancy's business is the sale of hardware such as hammers, nails, locks and hinges. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She has been running this business for a year and hopes to grow her business in the future. She provides high-quality products to her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Nancy started selling with 75.00 Liberian dollars as working capital, and now operates with 4,000 in working capital. Nancy will use this loan to purchase additional nails and hammers for resale. She dreams of always being able to help her family when they need her. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nancy is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional nails and hammers for resale

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas N. is currently in the business of selling greens and fruits in the market and is requesting a loan to buy cows to sell. Thomas is 47 years old and is widowed. She has three children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build houses for rental purposes. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy cows to sell

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leng A. is a 53-year-old married woman who lives in Svay Sar village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sochea Meun, are farmers. Aside from farming she also breeds ducks for duck eggs.

In order to support her duck breeding, Mrs. Leng A. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks. With this loan she hopes to increase her income to improve her family living.

Mrs. Leng A. is the mother of four children, three of whom are students in the local school while the other one is supporting the parents’ farming. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more ducks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying computer and office goods

loans.name: John

texts.en:
N. is 48 years old, married with three children, and lives in Lagos, Nigeria. She is hardworking and believes that women are helpmates and need to support their man in keeping the home.

N. is a petty trader: she sells drinks, snacks and spiritual items in order to make additional income. With the profit from the business she is able to save a little money and assist her husband in running the home. Her husband is a business man and is also trying to meet his financial responsibilities.

N. hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks and snacks to sell. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret J is currently in the business of selling beer and sodas at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell. Margret is 28 years old and is married to a policeman. She has two children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Igor

texts.en: Igor has a retail business selling shoes at Yulana market in the city of Zaporozhye. Igor has been in this business for five yeas. He enjoys selling shoes. His good prices and high quality attract many new as well as repeat customers. Igor's goal is to develop his business further. He wants to rent several more kiosks and increase his sales. Igor would like to receive a loan of 15,000 hryvnia to purchase more inventory. Igor believes that with hard work he can develop his business and improve his life.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Mabb

texts.en:
Mr. Mabb T. is a 26 year old who lives in the village of Pongro in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Raem Laem, are farmers who own a 5 hectare field to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, they also raise pigs, making a small income to support their family. This couple has one child who is too young for school. 

Mr. Mabb T. is now requesting a 1,000,000 riel loan from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline to support the crops. 

His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Nazirkul

texts.ru: Хушиев Назиркул проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 46 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Жена, торгует на рынке. Сам Назиркул занимается торговлей более 4 лет. Он продает одежду. Назиркул имеет среднее Техническое образование. До этого он работал по спепециальности, бухгалтером. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Nazirkul K. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 46 years old. He is married and has seven children. His wife sells on the market. Nazirkul has been in the sales business for more than four years. He sells clothing. Nazirkul has secondary technical education. Before now he used to work in his profession as a bookkeeper. He is asking for a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chultem

texts.en:
Chultem is 34 years old and she lives with her husband and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. They live together in an apartment. Chultem operates her business with her husband. Two of her children go to secondary school and the youngest child goes to kindergarten. 

Chultem and her husband support their family with the profits from their business. They started their meat selling business with 500,000 tugrugs (~ $351 US) of working capital in 2007. Currently, their working capital is 800,000 tugrugs (~ $562 US). Chultem has been planning to expand her business and to get a permanent job. She says, “I would like to expand my business and increase my working capital. If the working capital will increase, the profit will increase too.” She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of meat at wholesale prices for her meat selling business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Bros

texts.en:
Mr. Bros S. is 35 years old and lives in Srae Vong village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Saren Sann, are farmers who own a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, they are also salt and fruit sellers who earn a little income to support their family. This couple has two children who are attending the local school. 

In this dry farming season, they do not need money to grow crops. Thus, Mr. Bros S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, he will buy pesticide and gasoline to support his farming. 

His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Wael

texts.en: Wael is a 21-year-old man from in Gaza who lives with his parents and 7 other siblings. He is requesting a loan of $2000 buy more stock for the clothing store that he opened in 2008. He wants to buy more children's clothes to meet the market's demand and to increase his profits. He appreciate your help in improving his business.

loans.use: to increase stock

loans.name: S. Emma

texts.fr: Née en 1972 à Hêtin au Bénin, V. S. Emma vit depuis 17 ans au quartier Agbalilamè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Mariée à OUSSOU KICHO Basile, un professeur, Emma est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Agbalilamè. Emma vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les charges familiales. Emma n'a pas frésuenté l'école. Il y a près de 12 ans que Emma mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (savons, piles, lait, sardines, pâtes alimentaires, insecticides, etc.) à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Emma vend également du maïs et du haricot. C'est à Adja au Mono, Azovè et Pobè dans le département du Plateau, que Emma se ravitaille. Emma  a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Emma souhaite faire un approvisionnement en quantité suffisante pour pouvoir dégager une marge de bénéfice plus importante mais est limitée par les moyens financiers. C'est ce qui amène Emma à solliciter un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Hêtin in Benin, Ms. V. S. Emma has been living for seventeen years in the Agbalilamè district, in the town of Sèmè-Podji.  Married to Mr. OUSSOU KICHO Basile, a teacher, she is the mother of three children who are all in school.  The family lives together in Agbalilamè.  Emma helps out her husband where it concerns family expenses.  Emma did not attend school.  For nearly twelve years, she has been running a business selling a variety of goods (soaps, batteries, milk, sardines, pasta, insecticides, etc.) out of her home.  Along with this business, she also sells corn and beans.  She resupplies herself in Adja in Mono, Azovè, and Pobè in Plateau county. She has already benefited from two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid.  She wishes to stock up in sufficient quantities to be able to clear a greater profit margin but is limited by her financial means.  This is what's leading Emma to request a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods (soaps, batteries, milk, pasta, sardines) and some corn

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose loves groceries and that is why she is in the business. She sells groceries, such as noodles, milk, detergents and sugar. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future. 

She is hoping for a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She is a happy woman and she is so determined to excel in her business. She is 34 years old and married, and she has 4 children. Her youngest child is 5 years old. She is happy because her children are progressing in school. Her husband also works to support the home. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Awe

texts.en:
H. is a member of LAPO with a good repayment record. She owns a hairdressing saloon shop where she sells hair cream and hair extensions and braids hair for her customers. She manages the business with her three children who come from school to assist her at the shop. 

The income from her business enables her help her husband feed their children and pay for their education.H. is very determined and wants to expand her business. She would like to have an additional store where she can sell hair extension and hair cream and make more profits.

She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more hair cream and hair extension. This will help her implement business expansion plan, attract more sales, and increase her profits.
  
H. is 35 years old. She is married and has three children. She lives in Lagos, Nigeria. She sends a very big "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more hair cream and hair extension to sell

loans.name: Fayzinisso

texts.ru: Мусоева Файзиниссо проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 33 года. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Файзиниссо более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. Она выращивает оващи. В этой деятельности ей помогает муж. Кредит просит для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Файзиниссо хочет получить хороший урожай для продажи. У нее клиенты которые покупают оптом.
texts.en:
Fayzinisso M. lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 33 years old. She is married and has three children. Fayzinisso has been a plant grower for more than six years. She grows vegetables. Her husband helps her with this business. She is asking for a loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer. Fayzinisso wants to gather a good harvest for resale. Her customers buy in wholesale from her.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif G. is 46 years old. He is married and has three children. Sharif lives with his parents and is the main breadwinner for this large family. 

Sharif runs a café where he cooks different national dishes. A very good and experienced cook, Sharif managed to make his business successful. Sharif uses the income from his business to improve his family's living conditions. He also dreams about educating his children in the institutes and universities. 

Sharif is planning to make major repairs to his café so he can attract new clients and keep the old ones. For this purpose, he requests $2000 USD. Sharif thanks all lenders for their support and promises to be precise in his loan payments.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Major repairs to his café

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria owns a fashion store where she sells sarongs, clothing, tailoring materials and more. She designs clothes for sale, especially for weddings, engagements, burial ceremonies, and other social activities where special clothing is needed. With these, she makes her living. 

Victoria wants to stock her store with differed types of materials, so she is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more materials to sell and increase her income.

She is 35 years old. She is married to Mr. O., a businessman, and they are blessed with three children. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Odile

texts.fr: Née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, T. Odile est mariée à AKISSOUHE David, un pêcheur. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis près de 8 ans à Lokokoukoumè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Odile n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis environs 9 ans, Odile mène comme activité, la vente de chaussures, de façon ambulante. Parallèlement à cette activité, Odile vend également de la viande. Odile s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Odile est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l'institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Odile sollicite un troisième crédit dans le but de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter le stock de ses produits, ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Odile T. is married to David AKISSOUHE, a fisherman. The couple has three children, all attending school. Odile has never attended school herself. The family has been living for the past eight years in Lokokoukoumé, in the Sèmè-Podji area. The couple shares family expenses. For the past 9 years, Odile has been an itinerant vendor of shoe wear. She also sells meat as a side business. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Odile is a former client of ALIDé, having already been granted two loans, which were duly repaid in full. She is now requesting a third loan, to bolster her business and increase her stock supply. This in turn will increase customer satisfaction.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a taxi-moto

loans.name: Mrs. Sao Ou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao O. sells clothes and her husband, Mr. Phall Pork, is farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support his family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sao O. decided to ask for a loan to buy more clothes to re-sell door-to-door. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is an employee in a garment factory, while two others are attending the local public school, and the other one is too small for school. 

This village bank includes 12 people who live in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sao O. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. They they will use their loan for different purposes. Mrs. Him Seum and Mrs. Saroeun Seum are group guarantors so are included in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ajana

texts.en: E. is a businesswoman. She runs her business in Lagos and her family lives there too. She sells drinks to her customers at retail. With this business, she makes her living. She has been in the business for 22 years now. As a hard working woman, she also sells ice blocks and juice to make additional profit. With the profit she gets from the business, she is able to support and sustain her family. She is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more drinks and juices to sell. E. is 50 years old and married with two children who are in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Allamurod

texts.en:
I. Allamurod is 41 years old. He is married and the father of four children. Allamurod is a hard-working and enterprising man who constantly tries to do things better and to improve day after day. He works hard in his fields where he spends as much time as possible providing the necessary care, fertilizing his land and spraying to prevent diseases that might affect his yields. Allamurod needs tools and fertilizers to continue his difficult work, tending his crops so that they can be taken to the capital for sale. That's why he's applying for a loan of 6000 Somoni. Let's be the ones who reach out our hands to help Allamurod!  

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Gavharoy

texts.en:
K. Gavharoy operates a small business selling blankets, towels, and tablecloths and supplies in Istaravshan, Tajikistan. She has an attractively arranged store at Dushanbe market where she carries all sorts of necessary items. Gavharoy has been in this business for about six years and has developed a stable, profitable enterprise based on products that are always in demand. Her business has become the main source of income for her and her family. Gavharoy’s business is growing. She has requested a loan of $1500 USD to increase her working capital and help boost the further development of her business. With your help, this will be possible.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC.
