To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase blankets, towels and tablecloths to sell

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade is a busy woman. She sells daily from 7am until 7pm. She sells groceries ranging from toothpaste to noodles. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers to her business. She hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future. She is 36 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is six years old and the youngest is three years old. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband is a coach and he supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: Née en 1980 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, H. Honorine est mariée à CHEMADIN Emmanuel, un chauffeur. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 11 ans, à Davatin dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Honorine vient en aide à son mari et supporte avec lui les charges familiales. Honorine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a 5 ans environs que Honorine mène comme activité, la vente de mêches de façon ambulante. Honorine vend également des sachets, de faon secondaire. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Honorine s'approvisionne. Honorine a déjà obtenu deux prêts à ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Honorine envisage développer davantage son activité et augmenter le stock de ses produits, afin de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Honorine sollicite un troisème crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Honorine H. is married to Emmanuel CHEMADIN, a driver. The couple has three children, all attending school. Honorine has not attended school herself. For the past 11 years the family has been living in Davatin, in the Sèmè-Podji area. Honorine helps her husband and shares household expenses. Five years ago Honorine started selling hair extensions, as an itinerant vendor. She also sells plastic bags as a second line of business. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Honorine has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, and has repaid them in full. She wants to expand her business, increase her stock supply, and in turn give better response to customer demands. This is why she is now requesting a third laon from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy packages of hair extensions and plastic bags

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther H. is married and has five dependants. She has received a junior high education. Esther sells doughnuts and soya bean kebabs. She moves from place to place around Elmina selling to her customers, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is an engineer. Esther uses her income to help her husband pay the utility bills and school fees. Esther will use the loan to purchase more bags of flour, sugar, oil and other ingredients to make doughnuts and soya bean kebabs to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to save to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients

loans.name: Bakhrom

texts.ru: Пайгамов Бахром проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 30 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Бахром занимается растениеводством. Он сажает дыню и арбуз. Этой деятельностью он занимается более 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Бахром хочет расширить свой бизнес. Он намерен выносит свой продукт на рынок.
texts.en:
Bahrom P. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 30 years old, married and has three children. His wife is a homemaker. Bahrom is a farmer and grows melons and watermelons. He has been in this business for more than six years. He is taking out a loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer. Bahrom wants to expand his business. He plans to sell his product on the market.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nike

texts.en: Nike has a good relationship with LAPO. She sells daily from 7am until 7pm. She sells drinks and groceries ranging from toothpaste to noodles. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers to her business. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to own a shopping mall in the future. She is 30 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is seven years old and the youngest is five years old. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband is a pastor and he supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Enjeru Group 1, Kyenjojo

texts.en: C. George who appears in the small photo is also in the big photo and is the leader of his lending group in Kyenjojo. He is 40 years old and married with five children aged 10, 8, 6, 4 and 2 years. He also takes care of more dependants. George has been a farmer in Enjeru Iraara for five years. Although his business is mostly affected by the fluctuating prices, he is able to make between 50,000/= and 100,000/= profits a week. He is grateful for the financial support from Pearl Microfinance because he is able to invest more into his business, hence more profits. He works so hard to ensure that he becomes famous in the market for the quality produce that he sells and for having a respectable family. He needs a loan to be able to buy more fertilizers for his farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Jimoh

texts.en: K. is excited to take her loan with LAPO. She sells sarongs, cream and clothes. She hopes for a loan of 140,000 NGN that she will invest in her clothes business. She will buy in bulk to get a better price. K. hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support. K. is 40 years old and married with five children who are doing well in school.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and clothing in bulk

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena C. moves from place to place, customer to customer, selling clothes and materials at Elmina.  Philomena has a junior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. Philomena has been selling clothes and materials for some time now. She helps her husband pay the utility bills and school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more materials and clothes for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children and also to buy land for her family.

loans.use: To buy more materials and clothing for resale.

loans.name: Albert

texts.en: Albert has been selling second-hand clothes for five years.  He is a 35-year-old married man with one child.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, Albert has taken six loans from the MFI.  He really appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping him move his business from a smaller market to a bigger market.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy T-shirts and sweaters.  He hopes to run a wholesale business where he sells the clothes in bulk.  He dreams of moving his business to the Nairobi Central Business District in the future.

loans.use: Buy more sweaters and T-shirts

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: K. Jeanne est née le 26 Décembre 1962 et est mariée à HONFO Basile, un carreleur. Le couple a cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 21 ans environs au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jeanne assure avec son mari, les différentes charges de la famille. Jeanne  n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis environs 12 ans, Jeanne vend divers produits (lait, beurre, mayonnaise, moutarde, huile végétale, petits pois, conserves, etc.) au marché Tokplégbé à Cotonou. Parrallèlement à cette activité, Jeanne  vend également des produits de beauté (lait corporels, pommades pour cheveux, huile, etc.). Jeanne s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. Jeanne a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Jeanne sollicite un deuxième prêts de ALIDé, pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et augmenter le stock de ses produits, afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Jeanne K. was born December 26, 1962 and is married to Basile HONFO, a tile layer. The couple has five children, who have all had schooling. Jeanne has not been to school herself. The family has been living for the past 21 years in the Finagnon neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Jeanne shares with her husband the various household expenses. For the past 12 years, Jeanne has been selling various food products (milk, butter, mayonnaise, mustard, vegetable oil, peas, canned food, etc.) at the Tokplégbé market in Cotonou. As a side business, Jeanne also sells beauty products (body milk, hair gels, beauty oils, etc.). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and also from Lomé in Togo. Jeanne has already been granted a loan from ALIDé, which she has fully reimbursed. She is now requesting a second loan to expand her activities, increase her stock supply, and consequently improve customer satisfaction.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various food products (milk, butter, mayonnaise, mustard, vegetable oil, peas), and body milk.

loans.name: Olamide

texts.en:
Olamide has a hairdressing salon where she makes lovely Nigerian and western hairstyles for her customers. She also sells hair products like shampoo, hair extensions and cream. Olamide is 36 years old and married with two children. Her husband is an engineer and he also supports the family. They live in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. 

Olamide hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more salon materials. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more salon materials

loans.name: Fazliddin

texts.en:
Fazliddin has a responsibility that makes him work hard for improvement. He is farmer. He grows potatoes and maize, work that he hopes makes progress and provides what is necessary for his family. For that reason, he wants to invest in his production, expand his crop fields and improve the quality of his products. Fazliddin knows that if he takes care of his land and works diligently he will reap excellent products that will have a better reception in the marketplace. The request Fazliddin makes is to purchase fertilizers necessary for his land. Support this hardworking man so his effort is worthwhile.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Djuraboy

texts.en:
N. Djuraboy was born in 1959 and is married with two children. As an aspiring and hard-working man, he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. Thus, when he joined IMON International, he was able to make much progress with his previous loans, which he invested mostly in crop farming. For 20 years, Djuraboy has been growing potatoes, wheat and vegetables on his land. His sons help him with the business. Djuraboy wants his children to get a good education, allowing them to have a better chance to succeed in the future - this is what makes his sacrifice worthwhile. Thanks to his efforts and diligence, now his elder son is studying at the University. Currently Djuraboy requests 7,000 Somoni in order to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer. He plans to use the profits from his business to educate his children, improve the structure of his home, and improve the standard of living of his family.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Donald

texts.en: M. is 42 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is hard working and believes that women are helpmates and need to help the men keep the home. M. is a petty trader; she sells dinks, Gin and foodstuffs to make a profit. With the profit from the business, she can save a little money and assist her husband in running the home. Her husband is businessman who is trying to meet his financial responsibilities. M. hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is requesting a loan of N180,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy toilet paper

loans.name: Remedios' Group

texts.en:
Remedios L. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old. Remedios is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Remedios is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Remedios owns & operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. is married and has one child. She has received a senior high education.  Comfort cooks beans to sell at Elmina. The cooked bean is usually eaten with an accompaniment such as palm oil, fried ripe plantain and gari, which some people call red-red but is not actually red-red. She has been doing this for sometime now. Her husband is a trader. Comfort uses her income to help her husband pay the utility bills and school fees. Comfort will use the loan to purchase gari, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of the food for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase gari, beans and other ingredients

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu sells articles like cards, clock to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to grow her business. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more articles to sell. She is 41 years old and a widow with three children. Her children  attend school. Life as a widow has not been easy. She sells for long hours to enable her put food on her table to feed her children. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more articles to sell

loans.name: Olubumi

texts.en:
Olubumi sells medicine to make a living. She loves this business because of the profit. She hopes to grow her business. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization). LAPO, a Kiva partner, is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.  

Olubumi is 55 years old and married with three children. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a business woman.  She runs a beer bar in Lagos and her family lives there, too.  She sells drinks to her costumers at retail and from this she makes her living.  Veronica has been in the business for years.

As a hard working woman, she also sells pepper soup in order to make additional profit. With the profit she get from the business, she is able to support her family.  She is requesting a loan amount of N 180,000 to purchase more drinks and pepper soup spices. Veronica is 40 years old, married with 3 children who are doing well in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pepper soup spices.

loans.name: Mujeres Maravilla Group

texts.en:
This committee was formed by Mrs. Adelaida G., who lives on the 7th kilometer of the Murucuyá neighborhood in Ciudad del Este. She contacted her friends and neighbors to launch a group in their area. The group is called “Mujeres Maravilla” (“Wonder Women”) and is made up of 19 very active women from the same area who show great solidarity with one another. They have different business activities, and some group members were able to start new businesses in order to generate income and thus support their families. For example, Mrs. Ignacia V. did not have a business, but after joining this committee she became enthusiastic and started working as a street vendor selling clothing. She travels around, visiting commercial establishments in remote areas of the city. She earns good money and feels very fulfilled. She is happy to be able to help her family improve their quality of life. She used this loan to buy clothing like jerseys, shirts, pants, and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Staff

loans.use: Buy shirts, jerseys and pants

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen is 52 years old and married to Antonio Portillo. They have two children together. The couple lives a stone's throw from the center of town, where they have owned a corner store for more than 15 years. Carmen provides her clients with all types of basic food products, such as sugar, yerba mate, charcoal, dairy, soft drinks, noodles and deli meats. 

Carmen's daughter runs the store while she goes to downtown Itá or to San Lorezo to purchase her merchandise. Carmen has an established client base and has a cash-only business. She has been working with Fundación Paraguaya since 2008 and has made all of her repayments on time.

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, yerba mate and other food products

loans.name: Vitaliy

texts.en: Vitaliy used to make trips to Siberia, Russia, to make his living because of the high unemployment in Western Ukraine. A few years ago, he decided to stop this activity and start his own small business where he lives. His started a printing business several years ago. This type of business seemed like one that could bring a stable and high income. Today he has a number of repeat clients that order various printed materials from him. Vitaliy would like to receive a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase supplies for printing like paper, toner, paint, etc. He hopes to receive additional income and improve his living conditions. Vitaliy is not married and lives in his own apartment.

loans.use: To purchase supplies

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is a businesswoman. She does not own a beauty salon but she sells hair extensions at retail prices. She loves this business because she does not sell on credit. Her customers pay in cash when they come to purchase hair extensions. She hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She hopes to expand her business. She is 42 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is 18 years old and the youngest child is eight years old. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband is a commercial driver and he supports the home. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Estrella's Group

texts.en:
Estrella C. is from the town of Salay, San Agustin. She is 57 years old. Estrella is the group leader of a 21-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Estrella C.'.

Estrella is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Estrella owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Somaia

texts.en:
Somaia is a hardworking mother who takes care of her two sons and one daughter, who are respectively eight, six and five years old. She works in a sewing workshop to help her husband who is an employee of the Palestinian Medical Relief to afford household expenses.

Somaia and her husband managed to start building their own house in their home city of Jenin and this consumes most of their income; so Somaia thought of taking a $3,000 loan from FATEN to cover the last payment they have to make in order to have the house completed.

The family is hoping to move in to the new house as soon as possible, Somaia and her husband are the ones in the picture above leaving FATEN's office in Jineen.

loans.use: To complete the construction of her house

loans.name: Américo

texts.en: Américo is 37 years old and married to Silvia, a teacher, who is 34 years old.  The couple has an eight-year-old daughter together.  Previously, Américo made and sold flowerpots, but as business was not good, he abandoned this trade and began to sell milk.  Little by little, he acquired more animals and more clients, and now has sustained a business.  Américo is a repeat client at Fundación Paraguaya.  Through loans, he has been able to purchase animals, support his family and get ahead in life.  He is now seeking a loan to purchase a machine to aid him in milking his cows, as at the moment he milks them all by hand.

loans.use: To purchase a machine to aid in milking cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of office supplies

loans.name: Makinde

texts.en: B. is 42 years old, married with five children and lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a petty trader. She helps her husband keep the home. She sells foodstuff’ such as garri, rice, pepper and beans, etc. in order to make an additional profit. She assists her husband in running the home. Her husband is a businessman who is trying to meet his financial responsibilities. B. hopes to expand her business by buying more foodstuffs to sell. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Omotoyosi

texts.en: Omotoyosi is a Yoruba woman by tribe and she lives in Ibadan, Oyo state with her family. She is 42 years old and married with three children. Her youngest child is seven years old. Her children attend school and this gives her peace. Her husband works for the government and he supports his home. To earn a living, she sells VCDs (video compact disc). She hopes for a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. She hopes to make her business sustainable. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of office supplies

loans.name: Tendo Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
M. Saidat is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He appears in the small photo on the left and also in the large photo.

M. is a friendly and hardworking man with a strong determination to grow his business. He is involved in the sale of charcoal in Kavule and in brick-making in Bukasa. 

In his business transactions, Saidat is faced with the challenge of transporting charcoal from the villages to his work station. He needs a loan to be able to buy more bags of charcoal and to prepare soil for making bricks during this rainy season.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal and to employ labor to prepare soil for making bricks.

loans.name: Kenhinde

texts.en:
Kenhinde K. is a business woman who lives in Lagos State with her family. Kenhinde is 30 years old, married with two children. Both are in school. 

Kenhinde makes her living by selling drinks to retail customers. She has been in this business for three years. As a hardworking woman, she also sells pepper, soup, fruit, and juices in order to make additional profit. With the profit she makes from her business she has been able to support her family. 

Kenhinde is requesting a loan of 140,000 Nigerian Naira (NGN) to purchase more drinks, pepper, soup, and spices. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, pepper, soup, and spices for resale.

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola sells drinks and juice at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She is a widow with four children. Life as a widow has not been easy for her. She works for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her children. 
Bola has been in this business for a very long time. She is happy with her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to expand her business. 
Bola hopes for a loan amount of  70,000 Nigerian Naira (NGN) to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Del Rosario

texts.en:
Del Rosario is 47 years old and lives with his wife Delia, who is 52. The couple has a 12-year old son, Brian José, who is currently in 7th grade.  
Del Rosario began working as a tailor in Sao Paulo, Brazil twenty years ago, and after many sacrifices was able to purchase a sewing machine.  Currently he owns five different machines with which he works every day to support his family. 
Del Rosario is seeking a loan to purchase fabric in order to fill a large number of orders.

loans.use: To purchase fabric.

loans.name: Marilou's Group

texts.en:
Marilou C. is from the village of Gappal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Marilou is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marilou is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a butcher shop. The main source of income for the business comes from butchering and selling pork in the market. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola is 55 years old and married with four children. She makes lovely Nigerian hair styles for her customers. She also sells salon materials like shampoo, hair extensions, etc. 
She is happy in her business because she is able to help support her household with the profits that she makes. Her husband sells equipment to help support their household, also.
Adeola hopes for a loan amount of 70,000 Nigerian Naira (NGN) to purchase more salon materials to sell. She hopes to own a world-class salon in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more salon materials.

loans.name: Yepete

texts.en:
Yepete E. currently runs a shop where she sells various items. She is requesting a loan to buy bags of rice, beans and posho to sell. Yepete is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 5 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting and to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice, beans and posho to sell.

loans.name: Evarista

texts.en:
Evarista is 45 years old and has been married for 10 years. She does not have any kids of her own, but she has a 20 year old adopted daughter who has a daughter of her own. They both live with Evarista and her husband. 

Evarista has owned her corner store for 5 years. Previously her mother owned the store. After her death, Evarista decided to continue running it. Despite stiff competition, business is going well due to her good customer service.  Her current project is opening a hardware and toy store next to the corner store.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, rice and drinks

loans.name: Mujeres En Progreso Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del comité inició  la señora Deolinda A., quien vive en el barrio San Miguel de Pdte. Franco de Ciudad del Este, ella contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona.
El comité se denomina “Mujeres En Progreso”, está constituido  por 17  señoras muy activas y solidarias todas de la misma zona.                        Cada una de ellas tiene una actividad independiente y la realizan con muy esfuerzo y sacrificio.
Y cada crédito que ello retiran lo destinan  a la actividad que ellas se dedican así como la señora Olga quien se dedica a la venta minorista de muchos productos preferentemente de uso doméstico, ella atiende su negocio en su domicilio y nos cuenta que esta muy contenta ya que cuenta con mucha clientela y sus ganancias son muy interesantes por que ayudan mucho en la economía de la casa especialmente para la alimentación de la familia.
Así todas de dedican a elaborar y vender sus trabajos de la mejor manera;

texts.en:
Deolinda got in touch with her friends and neighbors to form the group. She lives in the San Miguel de Pdte. Franco neighborhood in the City of Este. The group is called “Mujeres En Progreso” (Women in Progress) and is made up of 17 active women from the same zone. Each lady has her own business which they run with great effort. Each loan is intended for their individual businesses, like Olga who sells many items, particularly household products. She runs her business from her home and tells us that she is very happy; she has many customers; and her income is important because it helps very much with expenses, especially feeding the family. The other members work to build their businesses and work hard in the best way they can; 1. Olga – Pantry sales 2. Deolinda – Cosmetic sales 3. Dolly – Clothing sales 4. Elva – Tailoring 5. Petrona – Clothing sales 6. Graciela – Hair styling 7. Andrea – Clothing sales 8. Dionisia – Empanada sales 9. Mirna – Nic nac sales 10. Angélica – Sports lottery tickets 11. Aurora – Clothing sales 12. Cipriana – Egg and cheese sales 13. Rosa – Cosmetic sales 14. Celsa – Food sales 15. Valentina – Fruit sales 16. Alice – Footwear sales (flip-flops) 17. Flora – Fruit and vegetable sales

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise (rice, sugar, cooking oils, flour, fruits and vegetables, clothing, jewelry, cleaning products) for resale

loans.name: Tugolokoke Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Eve, in the small photo at the top left also appears in the big group photo and she is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 40 years old and is a hard working lady with four children. She also takes care of her parents. 

Eve is a strong business lady. She has a retail shop and has also been a maize farmer in Kyetume for 20 years. From these businesses, she is able to make 300,000/= as profit. She says that she has been successful because of her good hygiene, customer friendliness plus the favorable prices that attract many customers. 

She hopes to expand both businesses in the future as she is a single parent and has a strong drive to continue educating all her children and to build rental properties for their upkeep. She needs a loan to be able to increase the stock in her retail shop so that her sales can increase.

loans.use: to restock her retail shop

loans.name: Sadia

texts.en: Sadia sells mouth watery Nigerian cooked foods and drinks to make a living in Lagos state. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Sadia hopes to expand her business in the future.She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. Sadia is 31 years old, married with two children. She is a friendly and hard working woman. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more  drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Felicita

texts.en:
Felicita is 63 years old and is a single mother of 4 children. Two of them are married while the other two live with her. One of Felicita's children who lives with her is in school. The other one works and helps support her. 

Felicita has run a corner store out of her home for 5 years.  She started the business to help her ex-husband. After their separation and with the passing of time, she was able to support herself with this business and grow it with loans from Fundación Paraguaya. She is a repeat client at Fundación Paraguaya because of the good service it provides her. Felicita is thinking of opening a diner so that she can increase her client base and grow her business.

loans.use: to open a diner

loans.name: Mukono Women Crafts Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Faith, pictured at the top right, is the leader of her lending group (and she happens to be in the small photo, too). She is 57 years old and a single mother of 5 children, some of whom have finished university.  She is also taking care of 8 nephews and nieces.

Faith is a business lady involved in the making and selling of crafts like mats, baskets and other items.  She also does outside catering and her biggest challenge are the seasons when the number of clients is inadequate.

She has operated from the Butebe zone for 3 years and she is able to make 100,000 Ugandan Shillings as profit each week. She ensures that she has quality products and, in future, she would like to make a big show room for her crafts. She needs a loan to be able to buy more materials for making crafts in bulk.

loans.use: Buying craft materials in bulk.

loans.name: Dalal

texts.en:
Dalal and her husband are shown in the photo.

Dalal's sugar-packaging workshop is the main source of income for the entire family, but this project is still in its primitive stages. Packaging the bulk quantities of sugar is done manually by the family into different weight packages such as 1, 5 or 10 kilos. Therefore, Dalal has requested a loan from FATEN to purchase an automatic packaging machine which will speed up the work.

Dalal has five sons and one daughter. The oldest is 21 and works in the Ministry of Justice as an MIS (management information system) officer while the rest are school students. Due to the big family and its living expenses Dalal and her husband, who runs the workshop, want to improve their work and be able to meet their family's needs and pay their education fees.

They believe that having this machine will help them achieve this goal, especially since their workshop is the only one of its kind in Jenin district.

loans.use: To purchase an automatic packaging machine

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice M. is currently in the business of selling clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Joice is 32 years old. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build houses to rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Manylyn's Group

texts.en:
Manylyn M. is from the village of Palao, Solana, Cagayan. She is 22 years old. Manylyn is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Manylyn is single. To make a living, Manylyn works in someone else's business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Manylyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Manylyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manylyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the first loan taken out by Manylyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Francisco Rodrigo Martínez

texts.en: Francisco is 29 years old and lives with Aveiro in the city of Itá.  He owns a bakery located in downtown Itá, which his father left him in charge of 9 years ago.  The bakery produces all types of baked goods including crackers, rolls and bread sticks which he distributes to local corner stores and to his mother's stall in the local market.  Francisco's father, Brigido, and brother, Mario, both work in the bakery as well. The loan will be used to purchase flour, baking powder, and little bags.

loans.use: To purchase flour, baking powder, and little bags

loans.name: Mpara Hiv/aids Support Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en: Robert K. (pictured at top left and also in the group photo) is the leader of this lending group in Kyenjojo. He is 44 years old and married with 8 children aged 4-22 years old, including 4 orphaned dependents. Robert is a hard-working businessman who sells produce in Rugando Musanju .  Although he works hard, his income from the business is low, though he is able to  pay his children’s school fees. He buys produce from farmers in the villages and sells it at the market. Robert needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale.

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.en: Ndèye N. is 37 years old, married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for two and a half years. With the loan she will buy more vegetables to sell at the market. The income generated from this activity will allow her to improve the living conditions and health of her family.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu sells electric stoves to wholesale and retail customers.  She hopes to be a major distributor in the future.  She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers.  Idowu is also happy that she is the only person in her community who sells electric stoves. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting  a loan of N100,000 to purchase more electric stoves to sell. 

Idowu  is 43 years old, and married with 3 children. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electric stoves to sell

loans.name: Comite Cerrito Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Cerrito, se conformo en fecha 24 de marzo del 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Antoliana Fernández, quien se dedica a la Venta. de artesanías, contactó con la asesora que también tenía un grupo en la misma zona, se informó del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y una vez asesorada acerca del ProgramaEl Comité de Mujeres de nombre Cerrito, se conformo en fecha 24 de marzo del 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Antoliana Fernández, quien se dedica a la Venta. de artesanías, contactó con la asesora que también tenía un grupo en la misma zona, se informó del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y una vez  que la asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 15 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 6º ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
 Es un excelente grupo gracias al  trabajo solidario realizado y continuan trabajando con el programa hasta estos días.
El préstamo lo  destinan para diferentes actividades tales como venta de comidas, venta de mercerías, compra de mercaderías,venta de artículos de librería, venta de bebidas, venta de gallinas,venta de frutas y verduras, venta de quiniela, venta de escobas, venta de ropas, ect.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.

texts.en:
The Cerrito Women’s Committee was formed on March 24th, 2008, thanks to the current general director, Antoliana Fernández, who sells handicrafts. She contacted the advisor, who had a group in the same area. She inquired about the Committee of Enterprising Women’s Program. Once she was informed about the Program, she was able to get 15 women together. They are now comfortably working together as a supportive team during the sixth cycle of the program. It is an excellent group thanks to the supportive work they do, and they currently continue working in the program. The loan is for their different businesses like selling food, selling sewing supplies, buying merchandise, selling bookstore items, selling drinks, selling chickens, selling fruits and vegetables, selling sports lottery tickets, selling brooms, and selling clothes, etc. All of them run their businesses to raise funds. They help each other reach the common objectives that they all have within the group and with the Paraguaya Foundation. They actively participate in weekly meetings and have formed an impeccable collective effort. 1 Antoliana Fernández Sells handicrafts 2 Cantalicia Q. Sells Avon products 3 Liduvina Colmán Sells food 4 Ma.Zunilda G. Sells brooms 5 Brigida S. Sells food 6 Rumilda Vázquez Sells clothes 7 Ladislaa P. Sells sports lottery tickets 8 Sadi S. Sells chickens 9 Josefa Morínigo Sells fruit and vegetables 10 Marisel E. Sells food 11 Fidelina O. Snack bar 12 Magin A. Grocery store 13 Nilsa P. Sells food 14 Ma. Griselda T. Kiosk 15 María M. Book store

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy thread and fabric

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.en:
Juan Carlos is 44 years old and lives in a densely populated neighborhood in the city of Itá with his wife, Lorenza. The couple has a school-age son together.

Juan Carlos owns a woodworking shop in which he makes all types of furniture, including closets, tables, chairs, drawers, and other items that he sells. He has been a carpenter for fifteen years, and has worked exclusively with Fundación Paraguaya.

Juan Carlos is seeking the loan to purchase wood to make some furniture that has been requested.

loans.use: To purchase wood for his business

loans.name: Asejere

texts.en:
N. is 35 years old, is married with three children, and lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is hardworking and believes that women are helpmates and need to support their men in keeping the home.

N. operates a restaurant and bar, selling drinks and cooked foods in order to make a living. With the profit from the business she is able to save a little money and assist her husband in running the home.

N. hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks and foodstuffs. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs

loans.name: New Day Business Group

texts.en: New Day Business is a group of five borrowers led by George B. M.. He is 38 years old, is married, and has three children aged 7 to 18 years old with educational levels of kindergarten through 6th grade. George was not able to finish college because of a lack of financial support. George runs a photography business, offering services such as taking passport photos and taking pictures for special occasions. He has been running this business for more than ten years and hopes to own a photo studio in the near future. George says he does high-quality work in order to persuade customers to continue patronizing his business. George will use this loan to purchase another camera to improve his business. George dreams of giving his family a better life. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase a camera

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is 54 years old and a widow. She has five children, none of whom go to school. Susan is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcoholic beverages. She is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build a shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more materials to use

loans.name: Bashiru

texts.en:
Bashiru is 60 years old and married with five children who are excelling in their education and businesses. He loves his business and family dearly.
Bashiru is a hardworking man who sells various types of drinks from his stall. He works for long hours in order to provide for his family's basic needs. He is requesting a loan of 150,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. In the future, Bashiru hopes to own a drinks company. He thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Marcial

texts.en:
Marcial is 28 years old and married to Yohana. They have two children who live with them in Itá.
In the downtown area of Itá, Marcial rents a retail space where he buys, repairs and sells cell phones and cell phone accessories. He has been in this line of work for six years and has an established client base. Marcial opened his business with the help of his mother, a retired teacher. He has been working with Kiva partner, Fundación Paraguaya, since 2005. Marcial also teaches classes on cell phone repair in schools. Currently, he is seeking a loan to purchase cell phones and cell phone accessories to sell.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones and cell phone accessories

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: Ricardo es una persona que cuenta con 28 años de edad, Ricardo tuvo hijos con una señora, ambos se unieron de manera libre son concubinos y ya tienen 3 hijos. Ricardo trabaja como transportista de pasajeros, es chofer de taxi. Si bien hay bastante competencia en el rubro del transporte de pasajeros de taxi, también hay bastante demanda del servicio por lo que se hace rentable el negocio. Como en anteriores oportunidades se mencionó que el transporte urbano es muy rentable en la zona del Oriente. El crédito fue solicitado para capital de operaciones de su conyugue que vende productos de belleza por catalogo, también se dedica a la venta de joyas de fantasía y plata. Ricardo tiene una buena experiencia crediticia ya que no es la primera vez que saca un crédito, durante todo el tiempo de la relación comercial él demostró un buen cumplimiento de pago en sus anteriores créditos.
texts.en:
Ricardo is 28 years old and has three children with the woman he lives with. Ricardo is a taxi driver. There is a lot of competition in the taxi business, but there is also great demand for this service, which makes it profitable. As we have mentioned before, urban transport is very profitable in the eastern area of the country. This loan was requested for capital for Ricardo's partner, who sells beauty products by catalog; she also sells silver and costume jewelry. Ricardo has a good credit history, as this is not the first loan he has taken out. Throughout our entire business relationship, he has paid off his loans on time.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Payment of debts

loans.name: Akingbala

texts.en:
T. is 45 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells clothes, shoes and bags to her customers at retail prices. She will use her loan to invest in her clothing business by buying in bulk to get a better price. T. hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children.
She is excited to be taking a loan with Kiva partner, LAPO, and thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and bags

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es: La familia de Andrea está constituida por 2 personas, ella y su hija de 30 años, las dos viven en una casa que es vivienda propia. Andrea cuenta con una tienda de barrio que la instaló en su propio domicilio, por otra parte en el mercado central cuenta con un puesto propio donde vende ropa, calzados y otros. Es una persona que es muy activa. La competencia en sus actividades es media ya que hay otras personas  que desarrollan las mismas actividades, pero está no le afecta ya que Andrea se dedica a las actividades anteriormente mencionadas desde hace mucho años atrás por lo que cuenta con experiencia en los rubros. El crédito será destinado como capital de trabajo, debido a la época de inicio del año escolar Andrea quiere  surtir su puesto con  mayor surtido de mercadería. Esta será su octava operación con Agrocapital, con un buen cumplimiento de pago en todas sus otras operaciones.
texts.en:
Andrea's family is composed of two people, Andrea and her 30 year old daughter. The two of them live in their own home. Andrea has a neighborhood store which she runs from her house. She also has her own stall in the central market where she sells clothing, shoes and other items. She is a very active person. Even though there are other people who have developed similar businesses she isn't affected because she has a lot of knowledge gained through years of experience managing her business and keeping track of sales. The loan will be used as working capital. Since the beginning of the last academic year, Andrea has wanted to improve her stand by adding more products. This will be her eighth cycle with Agrocapital where she has always completed her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Santosa

texts.es: Santosa es una jovencita que cuenta con 25 años de edad, el estado civil de Santosa es soltero, no tiene hijos y aún vive en la casa de sus padres. Santosa se dedica al negocio de la lechería, es decir comercializa la leche al por mayor la producción la efectúa desde su domicilio, Santosa cuenta con 2 años de experiencia en esta actividad. Su competencia es media debido a que otras personas ofertan lo mismo, pero la diferencia es que ella es muy responsable en cuanto a la entrega del producto final y por eso se ganó la preferencia de muchos clientes que se consideran como fijos ahora. El presente crédito Santosa lo utilizará para la compra de ganado lechero, que formará parte de su actual actividad. En sus créditos anteriores trabajo de manera optima, no tiene obligaciones con otras Entidades Financieras.
texts.en:
Santosa is a young woman, 25 years old and single. She has no children and still lives in her parents' house. Santosa works in the dairy business, milking the cows herself at home and then selling the milk wholesale. Santosa has two years of experience in this line of work, She does have some competition, as there are others who offer the same service. What differentiates Santosa from the rest is that she is very responsible about delivering the final product. This has made her the preferred provider for many people who are now her regular customers. Santosa will use this loan to buy dairy cows for her milking operation. She has repaid all of her previous loans promptly and has no outstanding debts to other financial institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dairy cows

loans.name: Arminda

texts.es: Arminda cuenta con 62 años de edad, es soltera, tiene 2 hijos pero ambos son independientes; ella vive en anticrético. Arminda se dedica a la venta de fiambres,  embutidos y abarrotes. Se dedica a esta actividad hace mucho tiempo atrás. Su negocio esta ubicado en el interior del mercado central, donde hay una gran afluencia de personas. El nivel de competencia es alto, ya que existen varias personas que se dedican a esta actividad,  pero la demanda que existe por estos productos es alta también. El destino del crédito es para capital de operaciones, compra de mercadería por las fiestas de carnaval. Es el tercer crédito al que accede Arminda en nuestra institución, presentó un comportamiento bueno en las anteriores operaciones. No presenta antecedentes negativos en el sistema financiero.
texts.en:
Arminda is 62 years old. She is single. She has two children, but they are both independent. She lives in anticretico (a type of renting). Arminda is sells lunch meats, sausages, and other groceries. She has been doing this work for a very long time. Her business is located inside the central market, where there are many people. The level of competition is his as various people are involved in this activity, but the demand for these products is also high. The destination for the loan is capital for operations; to purchase merchandise for the celebration of Carnaval. This is the third loan that Arminda has accessed from our institution. She comported herself well in the previous operations. She does not have a negative background in the financial system.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital for operation

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is married with two grown-up children. She sells women's clothing at a small open market in Melitopol city. She has been in this business for ten years and her experience helps her to select the kind of garments that are in high demand. Moreover, Larisa's kiosk is located at a good spot in the market, bring many customers her way.
Larisa is requesting a loan of 13,000 UAH to increase the variety of clothes she offers. She would like to purchase more inventory for the spring season. Increased sales will help Larisa to make more income and help her children with their living expenses.

loans.use: To increase the variety of her stock

loans.name: Khady

texts.en: Khady S. is a 55-year-old married mother of seven children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for two and a half years. She is an experienced retailer and will use her loan to buy more products which she can sell in her corner store. The revenues from this activity allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Las Cumplidoras Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Las Cumplidoras está conformado por 11 socias de las cuales la presidenta es la señora Epifania, ella es casada, tiene 5 hijos. Epifania se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir para damas, Epifania trabaja de lunes a sábado y cuenta con una experiencia de un año en el rubro. 
El resto del grupo se dedica a diferentes actividades, la mayoría se dedica a la venta de coca, abarrotes  y confesión de prendas de vestir ya sea en sus domicilios o en sus puestos de ventas, una de las socias vende anticuchos de corazón. El grupo en general tiene bastante experiencia en los negocios que desempeñan y es por esta razón son conocidos en la zona donde venden sus productos. Si bien la competencia en general es bastante amplia, el grupo cuenta con experiencia y también con clientes fijos que reconocen su trabajo y demandan sus servicios, por otra parte el grupo tiene bastante entusiasmo con su negocio que hacen. El dinero fue utilizado como capital de operaciones, unos comprarán más abarrotes y telas, A este grupo les esta yendo bien en sus negocios y quieren seguir trabajando y contando sobre todo con financiamiento para poder alcanzar sus metas. El grupo tiene bastante experiencia crediticia con otras instituciones financieras.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "Las Cumplidoras" ("The reliable ones") is made up of 11 members, of whom the president is Ms. Epifania. She is married with 5 children. Epifania works at dressmaking for ladies. She works from monday to saturday and has about a year of experience in the area. The rest of the group works in different activities. Most sell coca leaves, groceries, and work as dressmakers, be it at their homes or in their stands. One of the partners sells "anticuchos de corazón" (a typical dish in Peruvian gastronomy made of grilled bits of spicy beef heart). Generally speaking, the group has quite a lot of experience in their businesses and this is why they are well known in the area where they sell their products. While the competition in general is hard, the group has experience and also stable patrons that recognize their good work and demand their services. Besides, the group members are enthusiastic about their jobs. They will use the money as working capital; some will buy more groceries and fabric. This groups is doing well with its businesses and they want to keep working and above all to keep counting with financing to reach their goals. The group has quite a lot of experience with other microfinancing institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Olatunji

texts.en:
B. owns a shop where she sells a variety of foods including frozen food and milling tomatoes (a variety of tomato) to her customers. She loves her business and wishes to expand her business in the future. She is married to Mr. Olatunji and they have four children. They live in Lagos. 

B. is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to expand her business to meet her customers' demands. 
She is 42 years old and a hard-working woman. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Kuña Arandu Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Kuña Arandu, se conformó en fecha 23  de Junio del 2.009, mediante  la Sra Petrona J., quien se acerco a la oficina de la Fundación Paraguaya para informarse del programa, y contacto con la asesora para la formación de un nuevo grupo y  logró juntar a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto con mucho esfuerzo y esmero ya en el 3º ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
 
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.

La señora Gregoria Ruíz es una de las integrante y realiza una de los trabajos tradicionales de la zona de ITA el cual se refiere a todo lo relacionado a la artesanía como son los bordados en Ñanduti.
Es una de los trabajos mas admirados por los turistas en Paraguay y la Sra. Gregoria lo hace de manera continua y lo comercializa en muchos lugares, este trabajo ella lo hace conjuntamente con las labores de la casa, pero también cuenta con la ayuda de sus hijos, a pesar de ser una mujer muy sacrificada ella agradece por la profesión que tiene por que hasta ahora ha ayuda a su familia a salir adelante dignamente. El crédito fue utilizado para la compra de hilos para bordar, telas.

texts.en:
The women commitee Kuña Arandu was launched on 23rd June 2009, thanks to Ms. Petrona J., who went to the offices of Fundación Paraguaya to learn about the program, contacted a loan officer to form a new group and managed to unite 16 women who are very happy working, with a lot of hard work and dedication, already in their 3rd loan cycle, in a joint and co responsible manner in the program. They all work hard at raising funds, help each other reach the common goals they all share within the group and with Fundación Paraguaya. They take part in weekly meetings and show great solidarity in their work together. Ms. Gregoria R. is one of the members and she performs one of the traditional jobs of the ITA area, that is, crafts such as Ñandutí embroidery [a type of traditional embroidery in Paraguay, distinctive because it is embroidered following rays that depart from the center of the fabric. Ñandutí is the guaraní word for spider web]. It is one of the most admired crafts by tourists in Paraguay and Ms. Gregoria does it continuously and sells it in several places. She does this work as well as housework, but she has her children's help. Even though she is a very self-sacrificing woman, she is thankful for the work she has which helps her family progress in a dignified manner. She used the loan to buy embroidery threads and fabric. 1 Gregoria M. R. Ñandutí crafts and sales. 2 Gilda A. Crafts sales. 3 Claudia E. Crafts sales. 4 Petrona J. Food sales. 5 Blanca E.
