Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de telas, hilos de colores.

loans.name: Renato

texts.es: Renato cuenta con 46 años de edad su estado civil es casado, tiene 2 hijos que dependen de él, toda la familia vive en un domicilio que es propio. Renato cuenta con la actividad de venta de ganado vacuno, comercializa al por mayor en las ferias de la localidad, también en zonas rurales y en su domicilio, esta actividad la desempeña desde hace 14 años atrás juntamente con su esposa. Su competencia es media, porque Renato es muy responsable con sus clientes. El destino del crédito es para la compra de ganado vacuno, es decir capital operación. En sus créditos anteriores trabajo de manera optima, no tiene obligaciones con otras Entidades Financieras.
texts.en:
Renato is 46 years old. He is married and has two children that depend on him. The whole family lives in a home of their own. Renato works in the field of cattle sales. He sells cattle wholesale in the markets in the area, as well as in rural areas and in his hometown. He has been working in this activity for 14 years, along with his wife. He has some competition but he is very responsible with his clients. The credit will be destined to purchase cattle, that is, working capital. In his previous loans he performed optimally, and he has no outstanding obligations with other financing institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Iponi

texts.en:
Iponi V. is currently in the business of selling cows and goats at the market and is requesting a loan to buy more cows to sell.  Iponi is 26 years old and is married to a husband who is a farmer. She has two children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more cows to sell

loans.name: José Ramiro

texts.es: La familia de Jose Ramiro está constituida por 4 personas, los dos padres y dos hijos, ellos son casados y cuentan con vivienda propia. Jose Ramiro se dedica al transporte de pasajeros cuenta con tres vehículos propios un de ellos es manejado por él y dos por chóferes que le dan renta neta diariamente. La competencia en sus actividades es media ya que hay otras personas  que desarrollan las mismas actividades. El crédito será destinado para  el mantenimiento de uno de los vehículos. Este será su tercer crédito con Agrocapital, con un excelente cumplimiento de pago en todas sus otras operaciones.
texts.en:
José Ramiro's family is made up of 4 people, the two parents and two children. They are married and have a home of their own. José Ramiro works in passenger transportation . He has three vehicles of his own, one of them is driven by him and the other two by two drivers who pay him a net rent daily. There's an average level of competition in the field since there are other people who work in the same activities. The credit will be destined to do some maintenance repairs in one of the vehicles. This will be his third credit with Agrocapital and he fulfilled his payback obligations perfectly in his other operations.

Translated from Spanish by Cecilia Piris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle maintenance

loans.name: Bernarda De Jesus

texts.es: Bernarda De Jesús tiene 61 años, su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Su negocio consiste en ofrecer sus productos a ciertas amistades y vecinos que son sus clientes, esta mujer inicio a trabajar hace 28 años, por lo que su esposo no le ofrecía ayuda económica para mantener a la familia. Bernarda comenzó a vender tortillas y poco a poco con los ayuda de los prestamos fue obteniendo ciertas ganancias, pero  esto le ayudo a lograr experiencia en su trabajo pero la edad de Bernarda no dejaron que siguiera con la venta y elaboración de tortillas, porque se cansaba mucho y sufría de reumatismo, fue así que decide iniciar la venta de mercadería en general. Actualmente solicita este financiamiento para la compra de calzado, vestidos, camisetas, shorts, faldas, bolsos y perfumes. Por lo que sueña con llegar a tener su propia tienda en donde ofrezca toda esta variedad de productos.
texts.en:
Bernarda is 61 years old. She sells general merchandise to some of her friends and neighbors, who are her customers. She started working 28 years ago because her husband did not help support the family. Bernarda began selling tortillas and little by little, with the help of a few loans, she began earning income. This helped her gain work experience, but her age does not allow her to continue making and selling tortillas because she suffers from rheumatism and tires easily, so she began selling general merchandise. She is requesting this loan so that she can buy shoes, dresses, t-shirts, shorts, skirts, bags, and perfumes. She hopes to one day have her own general store where she can offer a variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Waldo

texts.es: Waldo tiene 47 años de edad, es casado pero actualmente esta separado de su esposa; el tiene dos hijos de 18 y 16 años, los cuales no dependen de él ya que ellos trabajan. Cuenta con casa propia. Waldo se dedica a prestar sus servicios de chofer de buses, se dedica a esta actividad hace mucho tiempo atrás, trabaja con diferentes empresas. El nivel de competencia es alto ya que hay varias personas que se dedican a esta actividad, pero también la demanda por este servicio es alta también. El destino es para refacción de vivienda, por las lluvias una parte de su cocina se vio afectada, por lo que desea refaccionar dicha parte. Éste es el tercer crédito al que accede Waldo, demostrando un excelente comportamiento en nuestra institución y en el sistema financiero, ya que no cuenta con antecedentes negativos. SE HACE NOTAR que si bien hay una persona más en la fotografía. la misma no tiene ninguna relación con Waldo, simplemente es una pasajera que tomo los servicios de Waldo.
texts.en:
Waldo is 47 years old, he is married but actually he is separated from his wife. He has two children ages 18 and 16, they both work and don't depend on him. He has his own house. Waldo lends his services as a bus driver, he has been in this business for a long time, he works with different businesses. The level of competition his high, there are various people dedicated to this activity, but the demand for this kind of service is high as well. This credit is destined to be used for housing renovation, because of the rains a part of his kitchen was affected and this is what he wishes to repair. This is the third credit for Waldo, demonstrating an excellent behavior with Fundacion Agrocapital and in the financial system and he doesn't have a negative background. It is important to note, there are more than one person in the photograph. They do not have any relation to Waldo, they are simply passengers that use Waldo's services.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair of home

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
Cliente es minero artesanal se dedica mas de 10 años de experiencia en este negocio actividad que la permitió solventar su gastos familiares cuenta con buenas referencias de amigos y vecinos  por lo que se propone el financiamiento 
Solicita crédito para el mejoramiento de su domicilio  . La Sr. López Fernández Gregorio  tiene 46 años de edad vive en casa propia juntamente con su cónyuge tiene cinco hijos en edad escolar
texts.en:
Customer is a small-scale miner. He has more than 10 years experience in this business and has been able to support his family by mining. He has good references from friends and neighbors, which he used to help him apply for this loan. He requests this loan to improve his residence. Mr. López Fernández Gregorio is 46 years old. He lives in his own house with his spouse and their five school age children.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home Improvement

loans.name: Benedine

texts.en:
Benedine is 32 years old and married with two young children, ages 3 and 4, both of whom have started their schooling. She used to be involved in second-hand clothing sales, but in the past two years she has begun operating a mixed farm near Kitale, Kenya. Her primary income comes from the sale of milk products to local residents, and she also earns money through her vegetable farming. She says that the main challenges to her business are the spread of diseases among livestock and that high employee turnover affects her productivity.

Benedine requested this loan through the Kiva field partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 30,000 KES to upgrade and expand her poultry farm. She says that the extra income from this loan will help improve her family's standard of living and she will be able to support her children in their education. In the future, she hopes to continually progress in her farming capabilities and acquire a bigger asset such as a cow.

loans.use: To upgrade her poultry farm

loans.name: Friendship Club Group

texts.en:
Friendship Club is a group of five borrowers led by Matu S.. She is 37 years old and married with five children aged 2-20 years old.  Their educational levels are 2nd grade to 6th grade.  Matu is illiterate due to poverty.

Matu and her family live and work in the Coconut Plantation community, which is on UN drive in downtown Monrovia.  Matu sells cold water and fried plantain chips to residents of her community. 

She has been running this business for more than seven years, and started selling with one freezer but now operates with five freezers.  She gives her customers good service in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Matu will use this loan to purchase one more freezer to continue to grow her business.  She dreams of giving her children a better education as well as good health care.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Matu is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El Comité Kuña Guapa, es un excelente  comité conformado en fecha 17 de marzo del 2009, integrado por 18 mujeres de la Ciudad de Itá,este grupo se formó  gracias a que la Sra. Gloria  G., quien anteriormente ya operaba en un grupo,decidió juntar a sus vecinas y amigas del Barrio San Antonio, para poder trabajar con el Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras,ahora están operando en el 4° ciclo del Programa y todas ellas están muy contentas ya que gracias al trabajo en conjunto y a la solidaridad que reina dentro del grupo,pudieron salir adelante y seguir aumentando día a día el capital de trabajo,que la mayoría de las integrantes comenzó con el crédito otorgado por la Fundación Paraguaya.

Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades  tales como:venta de ingredientes para la preparación de alimentos,compra de mercerías,compra de mercaderías para la despensa(azúcar,arroz,yerba,panificados,lácteos,carnes,etc),trabajos en manicura y pedicuro,venta de joyas de plata,venta de lencerías ,venta de ropas,venta de bebidas,confección de ropas, etc.
Es un grupo muy activo,todas las integrantes demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad, asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo.
Es uno de los mejores grupos que se encuentra trabajando con el Programa,ya que la mayoría de las integrantes del grupo siguen activas desde el primer préstamo y con eso demuestran solidaridad y compañerismo.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Nancy quien con su familia se dedica a fabricación de joyas finas de plata, ella sus hijos y su marido todos trabajan en conjunto, tienen además un pequeño salón done exponen su trabajos y tienen una buena venta, gracias a este trabajo logran salir adelante. Así como la familia de la Sra. Nancy todas las integrantes del comité procuran para salir adelante dignamente
texts.en:
The Kuña Guapa Committee is an excellent committee started on March 17, 2009 by 18 women from the city of Itá. This group was formed thanks to Senora Gloria G., who had previously worked with a group, and who gathered her neighbors and friends from the San Antonio neighborhood in order to work with the Program Committee of Entrepreneurial Women. Now they are in their fourth cycle with this program, and they are all very happy because thanks to working together and to the solidarity within the group, they have been able to get ahead and to keep adding to their working capital day by day. The majority of the members started with loans granted by the Fundación Paraguaya. The members of this group will use their loans for different activities such as: sale of food preparation ingredients, purchase of sewing supplies, purchase of stock for sale (sugar, rice, yerba, breads, milk products, meats, etc.), work in manicures and pedicures, sale of silver jewelry, sale of lingerie, sale of clothing, sale of beverages, sewing clothing, etc. This is a very active group, all the members show commitment solidarity, attend the weekly meetings, and engage in activities that generate funds for the good of the whole group. This is one of the best groups currently working with the Program, since the majority of the group members have engaged in the same business since the first loan, thus demonstrating their solidarity and communality. One of the members is Senora Nancy, who with her family creates fine silver jewelry, she, her children and her husband all working together. They also have a small shop where they display their work and they have very good sales that are enabling the family to get ahead. Like Senora Nancy's family, all the members of the group have managed to get ahead graciously.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of business stock

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
United Women is a group of five borrowers led by Oretha D.. She is 41 years old and is married with six children aged 6-21 years old.  Their educational levels are 1st grade to senior high school.  Oretha is now attending the adult literacy school program.

Oretha makes fried doughnuts and sells them to residents of her community in Old Road, Monrovia. She has been running this business for more than two years and hopes to improve her business by purchasing more goods.

Oretha says her doughnuts taste very good which encourages customers to continue buying from her. Oretha will use this loan to purchase more ingredients to increase her doughnut production.  She would eventually like to open a dry goods business, and she dreams of giving her children a good future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Oretha is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making doughnuts.

loans.name: Rukayat

texts.en:
Rukayat has a good relationship with LAPO. She sells daily from 7 am to 7 pm. She sells groceries ranging from toothpaste to noodles. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. 

She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She would like to own a shopping mall in the future. Rukayat is 30 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is seven years old while the youngest is three years old. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband sells tires and he also supports the home. 

Rukayat says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 49 years old and married. She has five children, ranging in age from 7 to 30 years old, with her two youngest still in school.  She has a mixed farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where she has been farming for over twenty years. Her main income comes from selling milk to local residents, and she earns supplementary income from her ownership of a small hotel and kiosk in a nearby shopping center. She says that the main challenges to her business are the expensive farm supplies and difficulty in marketing and differentiating her product from the other dairy farmers.

Alice requested this loan of 20,000 KES through the Kiva field partner, Juhudi Kilimo,to upgrade her poultry farming operation. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her have a stable, sustainable income to help provide for her family. She said education was very important to her, and she hopes to continually support her two youngest children throughout the rest of their schooling. In the future, Alice plans to own many more dairy cows and poultry which will provide further assistance to her family and their needs.

loans.use: To upgrade her poultry farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of Heifers

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Sarongs in Nigeria are worn by women, men, boys and girls. Nigerians love sarongs so the demand for them is high. Bola sells sarongs to make a living. She is doing well in her business. Her greatest challenge in her business is funding and she hopes to overcome that challenge. 

She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. 

Bola is 40 years old and married with two children. Her children are still young and they attend school. Bola’s husband sells shoes to support the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase musical instrument

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. sells provisions and cosmetics at Elmina. Janet has received no formal education.  She is married and has two children. 

Janet has been selling provisions and cosmetics for some time now. She helps her husband pay school fees and utility bills. 

Her loan will be used to buy more provisions and cosmetics to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more provisions and cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase calves
